B000BJS4BM|5.0|This is one of the best Limited Edition packs I have seen, and without a doubt, the best Madonna has ever released.  The cd is housed in the sleeve of a large card box, double the length of a cd box, which houses an 80 page notebook for you to add your own confessions (a bit disappointing) which has a few lyrics hand written by Madonna in it, and a large 40 page, super glossy photobook with extra pictures not included in the normal album sleeve with is very nicely done.  More importantly, this version comes with an additional track `Fighting Spirit' produced by Mirwais.  It's a great dance track, perfectly in theme with the album, and whilst it didn't deserve to be on the normal version, it's a good song, a real grower.  It has been added to the end of the cd, and not sequenced with the rest of the tracks. <br /> <br />After the critical disappointment of American Life, Madonna has stormed back to the music scene with what is perhaps an album as good as ANYTHING she has made in her 23 years on the pop scene. And that's quite a statement...  <br />Staring off with a bang is the 1st single 'Hung Up' which samples Abba's 'Gimme gimme a man after midnight' and is not ashamed to be pure dance / pop at its best. The 2nd track, 'Get Together' sounds like it has a sample of 'music sounds better' in the background, and is a really classy dance track, that took a while to grow on me, but is now one of my favourites. It wouldn't be out of place on her first album and reminds me of `Holiday'. <br />Then comes the stunning 'Sorry', starting with Madonna saying sorry in many languages, and then into a vocoded 'I've heard it all before' repeated until the banging chorus kicks in. Already touted as the 2nd single, this is a fantastic song.  <br />Future Lovers is reminiscent of Donna Summer's 'I feel love' and is also a nod I think to Kylies 'Light Years', but takes it that step further. Spoken lyrics take you into a driving beat and as the song builds so does the vocal.  <br />`ILove New York' is perhaps the albums most unusual track and actually reminds me of early demo's I've heard of Madonna, pre-fame! Its great, has silly, fun lyrics, a driving beat and heavy guitar backing. Not a single, but a GREAT album track that will put a smile on your face - it doesn't take itself seriously.  <br />Then comes 'Let It Will Be', introduced with strings and then more (yes more) thumping beats and great hooks, and this song has grown on me to become one of my favourites. <br />Now comes `Forbidden Love', an absolutely stunning and beautiful track. It reminds me of the 80's track 'Neverending Story' and backing that reminded me of Airs 'Sexy Boy', mixed with Human League - this is a true album highlight and a `pop song' in the true sense of the word. <br />'Jump' is perhaps in the top 3 tracks on this cd.  The spoken parts remind me of 'Words' from her Erotica album - it's a real anthem and will be huge if released as a single. <br />'How High' is yet more pumping great pop / dance.  <br />'Isaac' is a stunning track which starts with a beautiful male voice singing the chorus from 'Im Nin Alu' made famous by the late Ofra Haza. This is the more dreamy part of the album and slows it down a notch or two, but the beat is not forgotten.  <br />The album winds down with 'Push', which has a slower more grindy beat, and then 'Like it or not' which has a 'Goldfrapp / Rachel Stevens' beat which finishes the album off beautifully.  <br />The whole album is sequenced together, and yet even though the album appears superficial (and can be taken as such), lyrically it still has something to say without preaching or winging. What's clever about it, is not just the clever use of samples or inspiration, (some more obvious than others) but the way Madonna has delved back into her own back catalogue and been inspired by some of her own greatest moments.  <br /> <br />This is an album for those who simply want to let go, to have fun, to smile, and in her words ' to dance and sing, get up and do your thing'. The sound of 2006...  <br />MADONNA IS BACK - BIGGER THAN EVER...CONFESS... YOU LOVE HER! <br />
0307276902|3.0|It's interesting how freaked out people get over whether someone like James Frey has told the truth in his memoir \\"A Million Little Pieces.\\"<br /><br />After the Smoking Gun published, \\"A Million Little Lies\\" about the man who conned Oprah, the issue has come up again.<br /><br />This book, I think, would work better as a novel, than as a supposed \\"true\\" memoir.  For it is still a captivating story, evidenced by people getting excited by it and telling others they should read it.  But part of that excitement is because people \\"think\\" it is true, so it is more shocking than if they read this story as a novel, expecting exaggeration.<br /><br />It is the work itself that stands the test of time, even more so than its author, and its emotional and spiritual truth is maybe more valuable than any actual truth. Fiction is that way, it's mostly lies told to tell truth. I guess memoirs are the same, and often, even history (though sometimes history and journalism are lies told to support lies).<br /><br />It's an interesting musing, though, making me consider how I determine my personal integrity in writing, in all forms it offers.

This is the more dreamy part of the album and slows it down a notch or two, but the beat is not forgotten.  <br />The album winds down with 'Push', which has a slower more grindy beat, and then 'Like it or not' which has a 'Goldfrapp / Rachel Stevens' beat which finishes the album off beautifully.  <br />The whole album is sequenced together, and yet even though the album appears superficial (and can be taken as such), lyrically it still has something to say without preaching or winging. What's clever about it, is not just the clever use of samples or inspiration, (some more obvious than others) but the way Madonna has delved back into her own back catalogue and been inspired by some of her own greatest moments.  <br /> <br />This is an album for those who simply want to let go, to have fun, to smile, and in her words ' to dance and sing, get up and do your thing'. The sound of 2006...  <br />MADONNA IS BACK - BIGGER THAN EVER...CONFESS... YOU LOVE HER! <br />

B000BMSTMS|5.0|Yes, that Korn that was once popular in the 90s and so on is dead. Musically, they completely changed their sound (which could be due to their lost band member, Head) but to tell you the truth, I think this is the best thing Korn could ever have done. Old Korn may be dead, but this new Korn is alive and full of energy. If this album is discovered by more people and bands I believe that once again there will be a new uprising of bands trying to sound exactly like THIS Korn. <br /> <br />Okay, so if you have this cd, or are just looking at the reviews (buy it, believe me, it grows on you) don't think of this as a Korn cd, or even a Metal cd. Also, don't think about the song \\"Twisted Transistor\\" if you have heard it. It sounds nothing like the rest of the album. Just think of this as a Rock album, an experimental rock album. This is definitely the first Rock album in a very long time that doesn't look to copy another sound or easily fit into a defined genre. Korn have always been that way in a sense, except with their last few albums (yes, I said few, not one or two). But this cd will surprise a hardcore Korn fan.  <br />First of all, this is the 'lightest' Korn album to date. 'Light' meaning not 'heavy', in the metal kind of sense. The album begins with a short interlude (yes there are a few interludes on this album, much like 'Issues')and then there is \\"Twisted Transistor\\". Catchy, simple, 'pop-py' (you can thank The Matrix for that), but still proves the progression Korn has made. The next few songs are the heavier ones of the album, but still nothing over the top. \\"Politics\\" is very catchy, interestingly set up, the industrial sound actually sounds really good. The only bad thing is that the lyrics don't sound 'smart'. I have found that Korn has never been 'smart' with their lyrics, they usually repeat themselves by saying some of the same lines in the same album. But this cd is 'smart', just not this song. The main chorus \\"You want to sleep with him to get to whoyou need to know, think thats they way to go don't you?\\" makes it seem like Jonathan Davis is supporting good morals, which he never had in the past (or now, 'Getting Off' for instance). But we'll excuse this, because this is a great 'sounding' song, and so are the many others. The few songs that stand out to me are \\"Hypocrites\\", \\"Throw Me Away\\", \\"Open Up\\", \\"Coming Undone\\", and \\"Liar\\". Why? Because they're different. Well, \\"Hypocrites isn't so different, but its heavy, its simple, the lyrics are actually well wrote and get across the point about their old band member, and it makes old-school korn fans happy. \\"Throw Me Away\\" is the 'lightest' song on the album, but its very 'smart' and sounds great. \\"Open Up\\" is another soft song, but it has a great bass beat and the lyrics are very thoughtful. It is also the most experimental song on this album, in my opinion. \\"Coming Undone\\" is definitely worthy of being the next single. It has an enormous beat (if you heard it you'd know what I'm talking about) and a great element of 'fun'. \\"Liar\\" is heavy, strong, 'smart', and even brings back the old \\"scat\\" that was available in old-school Korn. Bagpipes here too, as in at least 3 songs, which is very good instead of the one or two songs that it was available in before. \\"Seen It All\\" is probably one of the best songs Korn could have ever chosen for a closer, but they didn't. The lyrics are great, the concept is smart, but they used \\"Tearjerker\\", which is an ok but depressing closer.  <br /> <br />My last word to convince you to buy this album is that every song is DIFFERENT. This is the first Korn album to give us this. Not one song sounds similar to another, the lyrics are different and for the FIRST TIME, Jonathan Davis does not complain all the time in his lyrics, but instead decides to sing about meaningful things in our world, like Politics, Religion, Relationships, etc. (There are also a few sex songs, also on the extra disc, but they're nothing special). So, as a final thought, this album may not sound so special when you first hear it, but listen to it, think about it, and you'll be hooked. It proves old Korn is dead and new Korn is born.

My freshman year of high school, not even a week into the new school year. This album is a tribute to the true art form of hip hop..heart felt emotions, street credibility, beats, lyrics and flows that are like a serenade from a man whos pain could be felt by any listener. Tracks like \\"Bomb First\\" and \\"Against all Odds\\" make Makaveli the end all be all for Tupac. I am surprised how those two songs were made in less than 7 days. Pac knew what he was doing, and this album is an indication of his genius. B000009HF2|5.0|If you weren't \\"of age\\" in 1976, then, I guess, you don't understand. In answer (or a question) to younger critics, why would you buy a live album from the 70's when your opinion is pretty much predetermined? Frampton Comes Alive is an event upon itself. Lets face it, his studio albums sucked, as evidenced by flop after flop before and AFTER this album came out. However, he peaked in every way on THIS album. FCA proves he was meant to be live, and not in the studio. I was an Aerosmith, Led Zeppelin, Alice Cooper, etc. fan when I stumbled upon this album (thanks to a very helpful record store employee in Torrance who turned me on to many good albums). I admit, the radio way overplayed the album, but by the time they did, I already knew every song they played by heart, and then some. However, you can hear the connection to the crowd on this album. So much so, I envy anyone who was there to see it. If you were old or young enough to buy this album, but didn't, because of its overplay, go ahead and grab it, you won't be disappointed. If you were lucky enough to buy it and want to hear it again, do the same. It never gets old, except, perhaps, for those who don't have enough good, live, music, to buy today.

They plot and scheme to attempt to get any girl in the sack by prom night, making for some hilarious antics and situations.  Oz is perhaps the most ernest of the group, who seems like a genuinely nice guy albeit a little dim. Kevin is the only one in a relationship, but he is the weaker, beta male who is hoping for the day his girlfriend (party girl Tara Reid) feels ready to take the plunge.  And of course Jim, the main character, the happy bumbling fool everyman who just wants to be cool enough and be liked.  In addition to the four is Stiffler, the devilish, super smutty, super arrogant imp who leads all of them down a road of bing drinking and foul language. <br /> <br />Besides their hilarious mishaps and physical comedy, this movie has an odd message about peer pressure.  Because the main characters were boys, once the boys achieve their goal they are to be pat on the back and told that they are heros.  Had they been girls, it would have been another story.  We do not see the guilt, the unsure feelings, or the fears.  Although I was one of those oddballs who made it through high school with my virginity intact, through them we see the social pressures that kids are subjected to become sexually active.  I felt that pressure, to be sure, but I was too unsure of myself and afraid todo anything about it.  And once it happens, it's not such a big deal.  And it becomes fun, but like everything else it doesn't become fun without practice.   <br /> <br />It's a little ironic that the star of the show was not any of them but the band camp geek who takes advantage of Jim.  The gal who on the surface seems so innocent but is the most cunning and worldly of them all.  Guess it just shows you don't have to be cool to have milage.

0307276902|5.0|When I put down this book after reading it in the short amount of time as Oprah did I told everyone I know about it that I loved it and that it 'spoke' to me. Perception is reality.  What I took away from this book was the feeling that it envoked in me based on what I could relate to, as well as the fact that it just plain hit home for me.  I felt understood.<br /><br />Why did I feel that way?  Because James is such an excellent writer and was able to document his stream of conciousness.  The fact that he doesn't use correct grammer and punctuation is to give the book more power and take you into feeling EXACTLY what he was feeling.  That is the whole point.  The feeling of being addicted, shamed and guilty with little or no self-worth are portrayed by this man regardless of embellished facts.  The reason this book was and is so popular is because so many people can relate to the exact feelings that James explains in the book.  That is, feeling the Fury, a void, an emptiness, and need to fill it with food, or alcohol or drugs.  The need to NOT FEEL.  This is the core issue behind abuse of any substance, the need for a vice and should not be misunderstood and CANNOT be created by someone who has not experienced the pain.<br /><br />I do understand embellishment to protect people and to shorten the length of the book, but that doesn't make the core story and emotions as a result of his life any less true.  James didn't make any money off this book, nor does he care about the fame and this is easy to interpret just by reading his work, his biography and watching him speak.  What would he gain from lying as those have claimed?  Absolutely nothing.

B00008G9JO|5.0|Jethro Tull was ubiquitous to 1970s AOR radio and the album Aqualung got as much play as the classic Dark Side of the Moon. There are many fans who swear by the earlier blues oriented recordings.  My first Jethro Tull album was Songs from the Wood so I am partial to this period of Ian Anderson's writing.  Heavy Horses is the follow up and captures the rustic pagan spirit of its predecessor.  While Songs from the Wood is one of my favorite albums, I will admit that it does not have the cohesion of Heavy Horses.  Yes, Songs from the Wood features some great tracks including the title track, The Whistler and my favorite, Hunting Girl. But overall it is a mixed bag that does not seem to flow smoothly.  Heavy Horses is much more uniform from song to song while offering some great tracks, The Rover in particular.  The lyric writing is still somewhat satirical but now more romantic and descriptive.  Anderson tells less a story then paints a picture on the title track and Journey Men.  This album is a nostalgic look back to an earlier time when man was in touch and relied on his relationship with nature.  Though it got no substantial airplay, it features the classic Tull line up at their best and some of Ian Anderson's best writing.

B00005JOFO|5.0|A homosexual affair erupts between two cowboys who, being poor, tough and from the mythological land of the Wild West, defy the stereotypes created by the reactionaries of Fox news as well as liberals of \\"Queer Eye for the Straight Guy\\".  The movie portrays the problem of gay romance at a time (the 60s) and place (Wyoming) where such relationships were highly taboo. <br /> <br />However, this film is neither intentionally political, nor ideological.  Like all good art, its point is not to moralize, not to take sides, but to capture the complexities of a human situation and cast a light on the personalities involved.  \\"Brokeback Mountain\\" succeeds in that enterprise. <br /> <br />During the film we are swept up by the drama and emotion of the story.  However, it is once we are removed from the movie theater <br />that we truly begin to ponder the psychology of Ennis and Jack. We wonder about the history of these two characters and about what was transpiring in their minds at a different level.  We wonder \\"What if\\".  Two close work colleagues and I spent every spare moment for a week discussing Ennis and Jack (as well as less important characters in the movie) as if they were people we knew. <br /> <br />Oscars for this film will bring shrieks from the American Right <br />and kudos from the Left.  However, one is to hope that the nuances of this film do not get drowned out by the roaring battle.

0441172717|3.0|note that this novel came out in 1965. i would not recommend it as an introduction to herbert, for those who dont know his worlds, because it is his first major work. the full flavor of herbert is only developed later. some of the space-opera flavor of dune is old fashioned, but some fine writing is contained within. indeed, herbert in small doses can be even more revealing than long passages: study the chapter header quotes carefully; herbert speaks to you directly there. i recommend after a first reading, going back to reread the headers only. another recommendation for those new to herbert: forget what you've heard about this being a novel about 'ecology' or some such. herbert's ecological concerns are a background to the main story. the large idea is changes to human conciousness under duress. remember this if you read more herbert. a few words on style. the concerns, attitudes and thoughts of the characters here and in herbert deal with more crucial concerns than any other scifi world i have read. the reader is definitely challenged to keep up , especially when the innermost thoughts of characters are offered. matters of life and death are pondered. self reflection is a way of life in herberts world. the inner life of his characters makes quite an impression upon first, and subsequent readings. keep this important idea in mind when reading: herberts great strength is in the two person scene. all his concerns and themes come through strongly in the two person dialogue, that clash of minds that drives his plots. the characters navigate a realm where human conciousness is the measuring stick: you must be able to speak your mind and defend your ideas (remember changes to human conciousness under duress). to close, i urge all new herbert to seek out the dune world sequels; the style and ideas get better. my opinion is the final 2 novels (heretics of dune & chapterhouse dune) are far and above the best. also, if you have never read any herbert, consider reading whipping star or the dosadi experiment first. these novels of the 'jorj x. mckie' universe are lighter reading, relatively, and fast moving, especially whipping star, in which i detect a humorous tone. frank herberts universes stand alone in scifi for the reach of ideas adressed, though i understand some may find them 'ponderous', perhaps. remember that frank herbert is often speaking to you, the reader, directly, through the thoughts and concerns of his characters.

The fact it was a BIOGRAPHY hit me in ways books rarely do.  I felt changed and also was able to understand what I went through during my withdrawls.<br /><br />Then today I read an article on The Smoking Gun website - [...]  The article is exhaustive and very well written.  The bottom line is James made most of the book up and what few events did take place were horrendously exagerated.  He NEVER went to jail after release from the center.  He NEVER ran over a cop.  He NEVER was beatan by police outside bars.  His girlfriend when he was a kid was NEVER his friend (confirmed by her parents!).<br /><br />As most addicts will state, we hate hypocrites.  Nothing is worse than a person bragging and exagerating how much they drank, smoked or took.  Getting sober is very hard and not something to be glamourized.  It is painful and you learn many things about yourself you wanted to keep buried.  Therefore when a person spills their life in print you emphasize and take note for their courage to tell the world.  To find out the author LIED for money, makes a mockery of what we went through.  There is nothing glamorous about blacking out or throwing up.  But to make it more than it is, well, that is down right wrong.<br /><br />The article also posted a letter of defamation from James Frey's lawyers.  The letter stated if they posted anything about their findings, he would sue them.  James also conveniently states he had his records expunged and are not verifiable.  Furthermore, most of his witnesses are conviently dead.  For a person that is so open about everything, I find it amazing he would not turn over his expunged records.  How can a person be open in one area, but not in another?  The only answer is he is LYING!<br /><br />Read the article before buying the book.  Look at their proof and then make up your mind if you wish to go further with A Million Little Pieces.  It is written in a style I truly enjoyed.  It is powerful and amazing, but it is also 90% fiction.  I am an alchoholic and James Frey made me feel violated.

B00003CXXS|4.0|It would be nearly impossible to trump the first Jurassic Park film.  People were blown away by that movie. The Spinosaur, being even bigger and badder than the T-Rex, is the \\"guy on the block\\" now.  Flying pteranodons are introduced on Isla Sorna, where they were once housed in a huge cage, now left to patrol the skies freely.  The Velociraptors have also gotten an upgrade.  They look a bit more menacing than the Raptors from the original Jurassic Park.  These new additions are what make this film what it is.   <br /> <br />The first film was set on lush pastures of modeled prehistoric land.  The setting for this film is far more delapidated.  This is the land the dinosaur rules.  The premise of the film is a bit cheesy, but you barely notice, given the amazing production and spectacle of the film.  Once on the island, all you experience is the thrill of the search and the chase.  The fact that a divorced couple are searching for their wayward child becomes secondary to the dinosaur action that ensues once they arrive. <br /> <br />I knew I would enjoy this movie simply because I love the idea of Jurassic Park, yet I was pleasantly surprised by just how good it turned out to be. <br /> <br />The DVD is bursting with bonus material.  It would take hours to get through it all - but it's well worth it.  There's an extensive \\"Making of..\\" featurette, a \\"New Dinosaurs\\" featurette, a tour of the studio in which the dinosaurs were conceived and brought to life, storyboards, DVD-rom options, etc... 1573223026|4.0|A Long Way Down has a very depressing premise--four people meet while preparing to commit suicide on New Year's Eve--but it is also one of the funniest and most original books I've read this year. Hornby is one of the few contemporary authors creative and talented enough to pull off a story of this nature, but he does so with great success. The book follows one continuous story line, but it is told in four different voices--those of each of the four people who meet on a London roof while contemplating their final jump. Each character is unique, interesting and has their own, very distinct voice and through them we are able to learn a lot about what motivates different people to try suicide and how it is often (though not always as the book demonstrates) possible to prove to those people that life is worth living. Hornby has done a masterful job of taking a tragic topic and using his skills (humor, good writing, excellent character development, psychological understanding) to create an upbeat, funny and very memorable book. I would recommend this book to anyone who has enjoyed other Hornby novel or just wants to be entertained and possibly learn something about human psychology. It is a very good book and you will not be disappointed at the end.

1573225517|5.0|This is the best of several very good books by Nick Hornby. It has the same laugh out loud humor, well developed characters and crisp writing of his other novels, but this book seems to capture the moment and psychology of its characters better than Horby ever had before. The main character, Rob, is confused and self-absorbed, but using his unique way of catologuing everything in life (best songs, best episodes of Cheers, worst break ups, etc.), he leads the reader through a very interesting attempt to discover meaning in his life and to get the woman he truly loves. All of the supporting cast lend humor and insight that make the entire book a pleasure to read as well as an enlightening experience. If you've seen the movie and liked it, this book has the same flavor but is much better, and I would recommend reading this book to anyone who just likes great fiction writing and enjoys a good laugh.

1400032717|4.0|It's really hard to know how to rate this book.  As soon as I finished it, I went back and read all the reviews I could find, just to see if anyone felt as I did about it.  It appears that there are as many opinions and \\"takes\\" on this book as there are stars in the heavens (something Christopher Boone---the protagonist in the book---would appreciate. <br /> <br />PLOT:  Has been gone over here so many times that all you need to do is read the book description or any of the other reviews.  Suffice it to say that it DOES have a plot, a dramatic arc, and a beginning, middle, and end.  And believe me, this is something really new if you've read a lot from the bestseller list. <br /> <br />STYLE:  Here's the thing.  The book is written in the \\"voice\\" of the austistic teenager-again, Christopher Boone.  Okay.  Fine.  I understand this and was prepared.  You can't say the \\"author\\" can't write, or that his style is \\"immature,\\" since he's putting himself in Christopher's place and writing with his voice and mind.  In this sense, the book is successful for it does indeed allow us to get to know the inner workings (or lack thereof) of young Christopher. I was reminded at times of McCrae's \\"A Tour of Southern Homes and Gardens\\" with its Disociative Identity Disorder slash Asperberger-like protagonist who manages to actually get out in the world and survive, albeit not without problems in communication and social mores.  So I get this part-that the book is written in Christopher's voice.  Problem is, it's a VERY irritating voice and at some point you just want to strangle the kid.  At about the third chapter, I thought to myself, \\"There's no way I'm going to get through this thing,\\" but then I fell into the style and was okay for a time.  By about a third of the way through, I again thought, \\"How the heck is Haddon going to sustain this \\"style\\" without all of us wanting to blow our brains out?\\" I was pleasantly surprised at how he broke this monotony-unfortunately, I can't tellthat away here without giving away a plot twist and injecting a \\"spoiler.\\"   <br /> <br />PACING OF THE BOOK:  The book went very slowly for me in the first half. Trust me, in the middle it picks up a great deal and really moves.  There are actually a few exceptionally tense moments that will get your heart rate up. No, it's not a car chase scene, but there is tension there and Haddon (or rather Christopher) handles this well since he (Christopher) is really the author of this book, not Haddon.   <br /> <br />DIAGRAMS AND PUZZLES:  There are drawings, math problems, puzzles, and charts throughout the book that serve to illustrate the way Christopher's mind works-or doesn't.  While these were interesting in a \\"Da Vinci Code\\" sort of way, I never really felt Haddon tied them into the story.  It did have me on the Internet, looking for more information. The \\"Monty Hall Math Problem\\" was the only one I didn't' think he proved-still looking at that one. <br /> <br />TITLE OF THE BOOK:  While the Sherlock Holmes \\"Hound of the Baskervilles\\" is mentioned, along with Christopher's obsession with mysteries, I was a little shocked that neither he nor Haddon made the title clear.  It actually comes from a chapter in the Holmes \\"Hound\\" book called \\"The Curious Incident of the dog in the Night-time.\\"  While not totally necessary to the story, it would have been nice to pull this in more. <br /> <br />FOOD FOR THOUGHT:  There are many, many interesting insights into young Christopher's mind.  Some of them actually make you think that perhaps \\"We're\\" the ones with the problem and that he's normal.  Example:  Someone will say to him:  \\"My, it's a beautiful day.\\"  He will then just stand there and say nothing, explaining to us, the reader, that \\"It was a statement, not a question, therefore there was nothing else to say.\\"  In turn, the person in the book who has made the statement thinks Christopher is rude.   <br /> <br />PROFANITY:  Frankly, I don't know why anyone has complainedabout the profanity in this book. The point of view is told from the teenager who doesn't understand society's \\"rights and wrongs\\" and is simply repeating what he has heard.  He never uses profanity himself, but rather just repeats verbatim what others have said.  And the profanity in the book is not used that much. <br /> <br />PROS:  I liked this book overall.  If you read a lot, especially bestsellers, and like something different each time (think Browns \\"Code,\\" McCrae's \\"A Tour of Southern Homes and Gardens,\\" or Martel's \\"Life of Pi,\\"-each of which are totally different yet unique), then you SHOULD read this book.  It is not like any other and is a good break from a heavy piece of \\"real\\" fiction.  While I'm not in love with this novel, I didn't throw it across the room as I did with \\"Da Vinci Code,\\" which REALLY was a let down. The best part of the book for me was the way Haddon showed up the parent's frustration with their child and this was extremely heartbreaking.  Very well done. <br /> <br />CONS:  I thought the idea and execution of \\"Rain Man\\" was better and more easily accessible to the general public.  Christopher's \\"voice\\" gets extremely tedious and there are ramblings, which, while showing us how the mind of an autistic teenager works, gets old quickly.  You get the idea after about three pages.  After that, it's just irritating.  The book could easily have been a hundred pages shorter.  Bottomline is:  You SHOULD probably read this book, but don't expect anything terribly earth-shattering. <br /> <br /> <br />Melissa Ellis review taken off Dec 27, 2005 <br /> <br />
B000001ESJ|5.0|\\"A Farewell To King's\\" is probably the second best Rush album from the 1970's behind \\"2112\\".  Songs like \\"Closer To The Heart\\", \\"Cinderella Man\\", and \\"Madrigal\\" show a very emotive side to Rush that would reappear decades later on albums like \\"Roll The Bones\\" and \\"Vapor Trails\\".  These songs each have memorable chorus and verse lines, and the guitar/bass/drum playing is still truly great given the short length of these songs.  Rush has always been a good hit singles band from my point of view. <br /> <br />The other three songs are more of the lyrical and instrumental showcase brand of song (these songs are:  \\"A Farewell To Kings\\", \\"Xanadu\\", and \\"Cygnux X-1\\").  I will say, however, that these three remaining songs are among the most sophisticated tunes in rock.  <br /> <br />For newcomers to Rush, I cannot recommend this album enough, especially when you compare its music to most any otehr album.  yes, it sounds somewhat like 2112 and somewhat like Hemispheres, but it really stands on its own (even though the track Cygnus X-1 is really part 2 to a marvelous sci-fi story).   <br /> <br />For casual fans of Rush, or for those fans who haven't listened to 70's Rush, pick up this CD.  It contains the most variety and surprising elements of any Rush album. <br /> <br />For the rest - the rabid Rush fans - like myself - let's go to the internet message boards and ask Rush to play side one of 2112, Cygnus X-1, and Hemispheres all in one concert! <br />What a trip that would be! <br /> <br />
B00003CXQX|4.0|I was strong-armed into seeing this by a young friend, and now I'm glad. <br /> <br />What it is: nice little character-driven movie, in some imaginary, vaguely meso-American time and place. The self-absorbed Emperor (David Spade with charming sarcasm)is forced to cooperate with a peasant (warm and loveable John Goodman) and inevitably becomes a Better Person. Requisite bad guy Yzma(Eartha Kitt) and her sidekick are scary but there's never any doubt that good will triumph.  <br /> <br />What it isn't: No historical events getting butchered, no legends ruined, no sickening love stories between unsympathetic characters inserted for no reason. (In a rare and refreshing move, Disney included a happily married youngish couple instead of manufacturing a romance and ending the story with the marriage!) <br /> <br />There's a totally new character in Kronk, the bad guy's sidekick who is not evil or sniveling; he's good hearted (just misguided) and not stupid--just very narrowly focused. I was rooting just as hard for Kronk's happy ending as for the Emperor to get his new groove. <br /> <br />Not a movie to change your life, but good entertainment (dare I say it?) for the whole family.

B000BP86OG|3.0|Justin Hawk sings like a faery choir boy and I have the impression that The Darkness takes itself only a little more seriously than Tenacious D. And Back', The Darkness has abandoned its freshly branded sound for, to be honest, cheesy glam rock. 0393327655|4.0|In The End of Faith, Sam Harris offers us perhaps the most blistering critique ever written on the possible evils of organized religion. Harris' basic premise, which is rock-solid, is that people are generally reasonable and only believe things about the world around them when presented with sufficient evidence. However, when it comes to their religious beliefs, their critical thinking goes out the window: people tend to believe the most absurd things about life, virtue and death, without a shred of evidence, all because they have been told to believe this by some religious authority or some holy book.  <br /> <br />In the first 2 chapters, Harris outlines his premise as described above. Chapters 3 and 4 chronicle the atrocities that have been committed in the name of Christianity and Islam, respectively. Harris comes down particularly hard on Islam, claiming that no true Muslim could ever come to any other conclusion than the need to kill members of other faiths. I'm sure many Muslim scholars (and practitioners) will disagree with him. In Chapter 5, Harris explains how Christian beliefs have led the US government to make bad decisions on issues such as abortion and the war on drugs. Although the link to the rest of the book is tenuous, Harris does a superb job of backing up his position. The last 2 chapters deal with the objective existence of ethics in the absence of religion and the possibility of spiritual experience without blind faith. <br /> <br />When he is at his best, Harris is nearly unstoppable: the thinking is clear, the writing is easy to follow, and the arguments flow. He loses his readers, however, when he delves into more philosophical tangents, such as what it really means to be an \\"I\\" that can observe the world and interact with it. Also, he also glosses over several obvious flaws in his argumentation: for example, none of the most murderous conflicts of the last 60 years (World War II, Korean war, Vietnam war, Rwandan genocide, Congo war) have had obvious religious causes. Though Harris does mention what he is against is dogma, not just blind religious faith, he spends awfully little time on the nationalistic or ideological dogma that has often had the same effect as religion.   <br /> <br />Overall, the arguments are effective: Harris deserves points for challenging the politically correct view that we may never question a person's faith and beliefs. He even argues that religious moderation is one of the most dangerous forces in the modern world, since it serves to disguise the religious wolf in sheep's clothing. Atheists reading his work will no doubt feel vindicated and understood. Ultimately, his point is valid: in a world where religion leads people to massacre civilians, fly planes into buildings, and claim land as their divine right, maybe it is time we started looking at some of these beliefs with a more critical eye.
B0006GAOBI|1.0|Just another boring movie that goth kids will pull-one off to. The pinnacle of pseudo intellectualism and kids who beg their parents to take them to Hot Topic, then pretend like they don't know them.
B00006DEFA|4.0|Here we have another example of an artistic genius made into only a semi-likeable person, in order to tell a story which does no justice to the man and his music. In order to sell itself to a large and semi-literate artistic/musical public, the music, terrific as it is, is once again put in a secondary level with a story that makes the great composer seem like an infantile, bathroom humored semi-cretin! Yes, there are some fine scenes of Amedeus at the piano as a youth with his sister and Dad supervising. And the costumes, and settings are all top notch! But can't we have a real movie about the real greatness of an eternally great artist like Mozart without the crassness, and feeble storytelling which is probably essential for ticket sales?! Probably not! Having said that, if you can forget the incipid general themes of the movie, including the idea that Salieri poisoned Amadeus, an old idea spread around by conspiracy-mongers,and concentrate on the historical settings and music, this movie is as good an intro to Mozart as Holloywood, or any visual medium, is likely to come up with!

0307276902|5.0|A Million Little Pieces by James Frey is a revelation to a person who has never smoked, injected, swallowed drugs. I, too, think it was important to stop romantizing addiction and make the consequences clear and honest.    The literary style of James Frey is quite compelling because it deconstructs an addicted personality and psyche. The reader lives the additction and the pain. The writer has involved the reader in his addiction, and subsequently dares the reader to take the ride with him to sobriety on his terms. It also made sense to me that addicts would rather help one another than work on their own problems. Afterall, they have been in denial for years and years. So it is not surprising to me that he gets involved with Lilly because he thinks he can help her. It is a compelling and intriguing story.    What Mr. Frey probably does not realize is that even though he does not accept the substitution of a higher power for his addiction, he has substituted a type of spirituality with the compelling matra \\"hold on.\\" This spirituality does not take on the same type of assumptions as AA, which makes it different, and probably what made it work of Mr. Frey.  [...]    Pamela Watkins

6305075492|5.0|I'm not going to spend time raving about the movie, because I'm going to assume that if you've got this far you already know how wonderful it is.  What I think could be far more useful (as this is an area where I have been burned) is some comparison between the two DVD editions I know of. <br /> <br />I have copies of both the Kino Video edition and the Image Entertainment edition.  My preference is for Image Entertainment for the following reasons: <br /> <br />(1) The print seems slightly cleaner (and most helpfully, the DVD packaging warns you about the horizontal line across the top of some scenes which is a defect on the original film) <br /> <br />(2) The intertitles on Image use the correct expressionistic style as per the 1920 release.  from what I recall, Kino's are the 'normalised' printed intertitles from 1923. <br /> <br />(3) The Kino version has possibly the most insensitive layer transition location I have ever come across.  For reasons of their own Kino put an intertitle before the final sequence in the asylum, and it would have been a natural place for a layer transition.  Instead they put it a few seconds into the final sequence (and only a couple of minutes before the end of the film!).  Image has no layer transition. <br /> <br />(4) Both scores on the Kino version are dreadful.  One consists of strange electronic noises, while the 'orchestral' one is pretty inappropriate.  Instead Image chose a very nice specially composed score by Timothy Brock which is a remarkably effective pastiche in the style of Alban Berg (very appropriate for an expressionist film). <br /> <br />(5) Image has a commentary track; it's not clear that Kino does (I can't remember, but certainly it isn't mentioned in the blurb on the back). <br /> <br />Just about the only plus of Kino is that there is considerably more bonus material (43 minutes from 'Genuine: the tale of a vampire' as compared to about 3 on Image).  However, if the price for that is the awful layer transition, then I know which I prefer. <br /> <br /> <br />So that's why I prefer the Image version and wish I hadn't bought the Kino version.

B000002VJH|5.0|The Dead are best appreciated live and rarely made the successful transition to the studio. Blues for Allah is one of the few exceptions. It's a marvelous album containing some of their strongest songs. In 1975 the Dead took some time off from their grinding tour schedule, wrote new songs and created this gem. Many of the songs became Dead touring staples including Franklin's Tower, Help On The Way and The Music Never Stopped. The melodies and playing are superb, the country influences heard on previous albums starting with Workingmans Dead are largely gone and replaced with a jazzy bouncing sort of swagger. But what really makes this album for me is that the Dead stretch out and jam on many of the songs including the two instrumentals King Solomon's Marbles and Sage And Spirit. That jazz like spirit permeates Blues For Allah and makes it more akin to the Deads live performances than other studio albums. Closing the CD is the beautiful and trippy Blues For Allah suite. There's a wonderful feeling about this very odd song, like an excursion into the desert at night with an atmosphere of mystery or discovery.<br />And that atmosphere somehow permeates the entire album making Blues For Allah a more interesting affair than any Dead studio album post American Beauty. That the songs were written around the same time, specifically for this album gives Blues For Allah a cohesiveness largely missing from other Dead studio albums. Many of their other albums seem to be collections of songs they happened to be playing at the time or those that hadn't been released on previous albums. But with BFA every song somehow fits with one another making a larger whole. I would argue that BFA is their second most successful studio album right after American Beauty.
0684833395|4.0|\\"It's a Catch 22.\\"  It seems I've heard the phrase all of my life and never been able to put my finger on what it actually meant.  Reading the book mostly clarified it.  A Catch 22 is illogical thinking, explained in a logical manner contrived to suit the people who make the rules.  For example:  If you are crazy, you should not be in the army.  How does one go about getting classified as crazy?  You'd have to tell the doctor you are.  Having the insight to tell the doctor though, means you are sane.<br /><br />It's difficult.  I liked it - don't get me wrong, but the man has an extensive vocabulary and really seems to enjoy using it.  Also, he's a bit crazy and reading crazy sometimes makes me feel it.<br /><br />It's an Anti-War story written about the Second WW.  I guess when Vietnam was going on these books were really important - they showed the pain of war, rather than the glory.  I've read a couple of them in the past year or so and I feel almost the same about each.  I get why they were written but I don't identify.  I feel like I've missed something almost by not having a comparative analysis of my own.<br /><br />It's also a black comedy, but by the end I couldn't shake the \\"black\\" enough to enjoy the \\"comedy.\\"<br /><br />I really did like it, I just don't think for the same reasons it became a best seller.<br /><br />The main character of this book is Yossarian, though he is not in all of the chapters.  He is a philosophical character whose anecdotes constantly put him in center stage.  His demise is heartbreaking, his brilliance is beautiful and his thoughts are totally soulful.

B000C65Z1G|1.0|That's the problem with this Meirelles offering.  A little old-fashioned straightforward storytelling would have gone a long way here.  That's what a movie is--a story with visuals, not the other way around.  Yes, beautiful scenery is terrific, but enough already with the over-saturated colors--they're distracting and remind us we're watching a movie.  Ditto for the jittery hand-held camera work.  Also, has there ever been a widely successful film with a Le Carre script and/or storyline?  No, and here's why:  His stories purport to be thrillers, only they're not thrilling.  They're just unlikely, incoherent and relentlessly downbeat.  Justin's \\"love\\" for Tessa and his willingness to forego continued existence because of the memory of it seemed unlikely to me.  She was a spoiled, wealthy brat who had almost no time and even less room in her life for Justin.  She lied to him constantly except for the one time she was honest with him when she admitted that her \\"work\\" (poking the Establishment in the eye with a sharp stick) was everything and that her life was nothing without it.  Additionally, the motive for her grand crusade went unexamined.  It seems that a drug company has discovered a cure for drug-resistant TB which will forestall a coming pandemic which will sweep the globe.  Unfortunately, the drug is not perfect and there have been \\"some\\" deaths in the trials.  How many?  1 in 10?  1 in 1,000?  This isn't revealed.  And when is this global outbreak of untreatable TB expected to break out?  If the pandemic is to begin imminently, then these are acceptable risks considering the alternative (no treatment).  If the pandemic is to start in 5 or 10 years then the market will address the problem with another drug company producing a safer treatment.  For a so-called \\"thinking-person's\\"-type movie there doesn't seem to have been a lot of thought put into the crux of the plot.  The storyline is as jarring as the camerawork.  Just being different doesn't always mean better.

B000066SBB|5.0|There's been only one of her. She is by far one of the greatest vocalists and artists of all time. They're all here. A one disc collection of her recorded work is, frankly, a joke - unless part of a series - like Rhino's The Very Best of Aretha Franklin '60's and '70's CD's. However, a two disc set is fairly acceptable, and this is the best you will find.  <br /> <br />Combining the lady's many Atlantic hits, and some slight rarities, as well as her Arista power house throw downs, is a God-send, that any fan will adore, and sew a special pocket on all their clothes for its carriage so as to never be without it(maybe, or is it just me?).  <br /> <br />Although thats not to say that only fans would appreciate this collection. And might I suggest that if you like this you buy some of her remastered reissued original albums, so as to hear the overlooked gems on each.

B000BW7QWW|5.0|Despite initially being somewhat put off seeing it by the rabid behavior of some of the more fanatical fans of the series, Serenity was easily the most enjoyable of this year's admittedly disappointing crop of Summer movies, so naturally it proved a box-office flop despite its modest budget. As if aware that this probably was a last shot deal, Joss Whedon manages to provide a genuinely satisfying finale to the dominant plot-thread of the series that leaves just enough of an opening for further adventures if the DVD sales pick up. But beyond that, he takes some surprising chances, particularly his willingness to kill off key cast members (one of the few areas where seeing the TV series actually is necessary: without their backstories it's unlikely their genuinely unexpected deaths would be quite so affecting), providing a sci-fi movie that's not just sassy and funny but also surprisingly touching as well. Certainly in the film's final moments you get a real sense that this has been made with real love for the characters and the setting rather than by focus groups and merchandizing arms, something long missing from sci-fi movies: the final lines could just as easily apply to the film's box-office rivals as they do to the Serenity.     Some of the regular cast members do tend to get sidelined, it's true, but never to the extent that you feel cheated - not least because it avoids the Star Trek movies trap of adding redundant big scenes for each of the fan favorites to lure them back. And in Chiwetel  Ejiofor's Operative, very much a logical evolution of Richard Brook's calmly pathological bounty hunter in the Firefly episode Objects in Space, he creates an intriguing villain, a true believer with a coldly rational mind, regarding himself as a necessary and monstrous evil creating a world without sin in which he will have no place.     The setpieces are both fun and ingenious (not least the way they manage to break through the bad guys' blockade) but not without consequences, and the big secret at the heart of the conspiracy actually makes sense. The only slight minus was the addition of sound effects to the space sequences, when their appropriately silent small screen equivalents seemed so much more novel and memorable. Eminently shiny.    The extras are good, but be warned that there will apparently be even more extras on the UK and, especially, Australian DVDs.
B0000DYJM6|4.0|It arrived today and like a teenager waiting for his parents to leave for the weekend, I waited for my girlfriend's next door neighbor to clear out before I put it on (I gave in half an hour ago). <br /> <br />I just finished the first disc and I am knocked out! There is a lot on here to digest-many different musical styles, many different time periods. Some stuff I've heard before, some I haven't and some I can't stop listening to.  <br /> <br />Disc I Song-by-Song: <br /> <br />\\"All Night\\" is a fun little punk romp. \\"Sad\\" is a powerful song of loss that affirms love and memory will always trump death. \\"Down\\" is a bouncy, moving-on type song-an upbeat \\"Rearviewmirror.\\" \\"Hitchhiker\\" is a kind of fun, throwaway diddy. \\"Don't Gimme No Lip\\"... eh, it's there. Kind of like when Stewart Copeland would do vocals on Police songs-it's for hardcore PJ/Stone fans. \\"Alone\\"-PJ people will know this one. This was my song when I got kicked out of college. Gen X-ers will remember their abject alienation. Beware though, this version is a bit different sounding from the bootleg. Fans will miss the raw-ness of the live version from '93 or so. \\"In the Moonlight\\"-this is a cool song-kudos Matt Cameron! Driving beat and check-out those melodies. This song is quite a departure. The only problem is it's too short and doesn't sound like it was finished. \\"Education\\"-The Doors anyone? It starts off that way, then turns into that primeval moaning Vedder has trademarked. \\"Black, Red, Yellow\\" and \\"U\\"-these were left off of \\"No Code\\" and \\"Yield\\" respectively for a reason. The bridge on \\"BRY\\" is reminiscent of \\"In Hiding.\\" \\"Leavin' Here\\"-PJ doing their best Motown rave-up. It reminds me of that footage from \\"The Kids are Alright\\" where The Who cover Martha and the Vandellas-dance Pete! Oh but it gets even better, \\"Gremmie Out of Control\\"-Vedder and Company doing... SURF MUSIC! That's right, cowabunga dude! Vedder's vocals do not gel with this material but it's always interesting to hear an artistdo something different. \\"Whale Song,\\" uh... yeah, the keyboards are interesting-very 80s New Wave maybe(?) \\"Undone\\"-quietly politically polemical ala PJ (one reason I do luv them so). \\"Hold On\\" was done during the \\"Vs.\\" sessions and will remind you of \\"Dissident.\\"  <br /> <br />Finally,, we come to, you guessed it \\"Yellow Ledbetter.\\" The comparisons to Hendrix are trite and not worth rehashing. This song has had a couple of working titles (I think) including \\"Ledbetter Blues.\\" What can I say, the liner notes quote Mike as saying he \\"doesn't know what it's about and doesn't want to!\\" Anyone who's lost a friend to drug abuse knows what it's about-\\"Can you see him... walking away.\\" Much better and understated than \\"Save You\\" off of \\"Riot Act.\\" I remember I was coming back from a funeral to drop off my car at the mechanic's and this one was playing on the radio on the ride over. I couldn't believe it, I almost lost it right there in the lot.  <br /> <br />That's always been the thing with Pearl Jam for me, I've always been able to personalize the songs to something I've been through or thought about. Overall, it's a great compilation. Admittedly, the best stuff is from their earlier period but the newer stuff is still relevant.  <br /> <br />This is the first time I've listened to Pearl Jam sober in quite some time (it's not an insult) but that could change as the evening progresses.

0307276902|1.0|I just finished reading this book about a week ago and as a recovering alcoholic and crack addict myself, it did not ring true from page 1. If it was as easy to stop using as Frey made it out to be after just making up his mind to stop, there would be no need for rehab and ongoing treatment programs in the world! Sure he gives a good portrayal of the depths to which we do sink, but his supposed journey of how he quit is just too pat and oversimplified even amidst all his descriptions of the supposed depths of his addictions. I do believe he was in rehab. I do believe he drank to much and did some drugs when he was younger. Naughty boy. But to call himself an' addict and an alcoholic', and imply that in the end all he really needed to do was just make the `choice' to quit, is dangerous for the true addict or alcoholic as well as the dangerous to the people that love them. <br /> <br />Regardless of what Frey embellished, (in my opinion a lot more than what is being proved by TSG) the real problem with this book is that it has put back the whole field of recovery a half century or more! First of all, most addicts do not have parents that will send them to a rehab costing thousands of dollars to recover. Most TRUE addicts have made the 'choice' over and over to quit without a program only to relapse again and again. Does anyone really think we ENJOY killing ourselves, slowly, hurting the people that love us, losing our lives, killing ourselves slowly? If it was really just a matter of making the choiec to quit, don't you think we would all be just quitting without ongoing recovery program such as AA or SMART? Quitting on our own without a support program is impossible for the majority of us addicts. As an addict and alcoholic myself, I do not believe James Frey is or ever was a true addict or alcoholic. Writing his book to portray himself as such is his true crime.  <br /> <br />This book may be an inspiration for some addicts and I am sure ALL the people that love anaddict. We all want HOPE! But in this case it is a false hope at best, maybe according to the latest developments, even a `fictitious' hope.  <br /> <br />My deep concern is that too many people that love an addict are going to read this book and have the false expectation that their addict will just read it and quit the next day. My other huge concern is that Frey's put down's of the AA 12 step support as being, his words something to the effect of:  `weak and substituting one addiction for another...the meetings' will be detrimental to the millions of addicts that might otherwise seek this program out as a means of support for quitting. I for one am very happy that this book has been exposed as a possible work of fiction. I hope that the publishers will go one step further and place it where it belongs, in the FICTION catagory!  <br /> <br />Belittling a program such as the AA 12 Step Recovery is dangerous ground to be walking on. For a majority of us addicts, this is the only affordable place we can seek help. What will Oprah and Frey do when addicts start committing suicide because all of a sudden there is a book out there that tells their families and society around them that all they need to do is `decide to quit'? What if the addict reads it and says to themselves, 'if James can do it, so can I\\", but falls back into the addiction? They will feel even more weak because some stupid author who is possibly not even an addict said all he did was make the choice to quit and did it! Addicts already have very fragile self-worth. Failing to live up to this book with all of it's popularity and endorsement by someone as powerful as Oprah? Heaven forbid the poor addict can't do it!What if the addicts can't afford to go to a rehab center for months? What if they were contemplating going to AA but because of Frey's book say it is useless?  <br /> <br />There is a much bigger crime in Frey's book than embellishing a criminal past that did not exist. Embellishing an addiction that didn't exist and consequently being able to miraculously conquer it for good `just like that' is the real issue I have with this book. I apologize for this being so long, but I don't want anyone to be given FALSE hope. <br />

B00005KB9R|5.0|This is not \\"Bob Marley and the Wailers.\\" That's an anachronism. Bob Marley and the Wailers didn't come into existence until after the breakup of the original Wailers. This is the masterpiece of that original band. Marley's solo work was brilliant, of course, but it's a different kettle of fish from what you get here. Here you get the vocal and spiritual harmonies of three great musicians -- Marley, Tosh, and Bunny Wailer. 1565847032|5.0|Chomsky has written so much so its hard to know where to begin and almost impossible to read it all. So a \\"best of chomsky\\" type of book is very useful. Together it comprises and education between two covers that will give you new way of thinking about the world and our (US) place in it.  <br /> <br />The beautiful thing about Chomsky's writing and philosophy is to have a clear moral/legal view and apply the same standards to ourselves that we apply to others. His basis in lingistics is very scientific and he applies the same sort of definitions and applications of ideals to the behaviour of nations in a Euclidean sort of way. (E.g. he shows that our common use of the word \\"terrorism\\" comes down to things other people do to us but not the other way around) Those who disagree with him, are merely showing the degree to which they are indoctrinated with propoganda and not able to follow his principles intellectually or morally. Often his detractor's arguments revolve concepts such as \\"We have a special right to ...\\" (invade a country, occupy a country, befriend a tyrant, etc.). No conservative can debate Chomsky, and phoneys like Ann Coulter fall of their chairs when they learn Pat Tilman was a Chomsky fan). <br /> <br />The only criticism I have is that much of the prime of Chomsky's writing seems to have taken place in the 1980's. Of course he is still active to this day and speaks out about the US and Middle East and other places. But the attention to Central America and Cambodia seem (I hate to say) no longer of much relevance in a specific way. Of course they are very relevant in a general way because the same types of things continue to go on daily.  <br /> <br />I also liked Chomsky's book on the Middle East illusions, and the little book \\"The spectacular success of propoganda\\" is the subtitle. 0517123207|1.0|Even though it was fun to read, I give it one star lest the brainwashed academics out their suffer further undue influence.  This book has been highly misrepresented by evolutionists for decades.  One reviewer made this point but failed to back it up with any facts.  That reviewer failed to point out that it was in the \\"Descent of Man,\\" not \\"Origin of the Species\\" where Darwin first presents man as having descended from apes.    Evolutionists apply natural selection to explain all biological development.  It's the worse case of reductionism in history.  James D. Watson and Edward Wilson were on the Charlie Rose show talking about this book.  They described natural selection as the single great development in science since Newton.  They claimed to describe this book as great English literature yet they badly misrepresented it as teaching that natural selection applies to everything biological.  How could these allegedly great scientists be so unscientific?  Scientists aren't supposed to be cavalier in their judgment.  Scientists are supposed to be conservative in their judgment.     First of all, let's quote Darwin himself from this book, page 75:  \\"To suppose that the eye with all its inimitable contrivances for adjusting the focus to different distances, for admitting different amounts of light, and for the correction of spherical and chromatic aberration, could have been formed by natural selection, seems, I freely confess, absurd in the highest degree.\\"  There you have it, from Darwin himself, from his famous book.  Yet, today, textbooks that claim a lineage to Darwin, depict evolutionary trees of everything biological sprouting from natural selection.  Evolutionists like Robert H Hurlbutt, oppose William Paley's design argument because it makes God, not natural selection, the origin of design in the human eye.  See Hurlbutt's book, page 173, \\"Hume, Newton and the Design Argument.\\"  Watson and Wilson also attacked the human eye argument in an ad hominem way without producing any argument.    But, while Hurlbutt is a typical product of academic brainwashing, which passes for education these days, how could two Nobel Prize winners of science, Watson and Wilson, make such a foolish mistake?  First of all, Watson and Wilson are crooks.  Their Nobel Prize fame for unlocking the secrets of the structure of DNA was illfounded.  Rosalind Franklin of King's college is well known to have discovered the structure of DNA and her supervisor Wilson passed it on to Watson and Crick, who, along with Wilson, took credit for it.  A little research by the Nobel Prize committee would have discovered this.  I guess the Nobel Prize really isn't worth anything when you consider how sloppy they are in giving their awards.  Einstein was given a Nobel Prize even though his papers on Brownian movement are a plagarization of Josiah Willard Gibb's book \\"Statistical Mechanics.\\"    Concluding unscientific postscript: Could Darwin's \\"Descent of Man\\" have psychological origin in the fact that Darwin himself looked like a monkey?
B000002JSN|4.0|Physical Grafitti, Led Zeppelin's sixth studio album, was released in 1975. <br />The band was at the top of their game in that time. With releases like Led Zeppelin II or ZOSO, They became gods of rock n' roll and influenced many musicans with their blues-rock style. However, when Houses Of The Holy was released in 1973, They left their blues roots and started to experimentate with various styles. The follow-up to that album, Physical Grafitti, is also not quite essential Zepp release, nevertheless it's an excellent album. On this record, the band uses hardrock, but darker and experimental sound. They also add various elements of many styles to the music here. There is some blues, sythenizers, folk, and much more. The final result is excellent. <br /> <br />Custard Pie opens the first disc of the album. Though it's not its strongest track, it's a really good opener. This rocker is just classic Zeppelin rock. Bonham's drumming gives this song a funky sound.  <br /> <br />The Rover is one of my favourites on the album. The riffing is great and the song has a dark sound overall. Just a very cool rocker that You'll surely grow to like. <br /> <br />In My Time Of Dying is dramatic and mysterious rock opera. Jimmy Page shreds out some good riffs and Plant gives a fine vocal performance. For Me, however, this song is a little too long and a bit repetitive. Not to say I don't like long songs, but in this particular one the band repeats the same parts over n' over again and in moments doesn't manage to keep things interesting. It's still pretty good, though. <br /> <br />Houses Of The Holy is a leftover from earlier album of the same title. Actually this song would fit pretty well there, but it also fits well here. A good, funny and happy rocker. The lead riff is very catchy and the entire song is excellent. <br /> <br />Trampled Under Foot is another killer tune. Page's riffing, suported by Bonham's drum beat, shakes Your body to dance. John Paul Jones does a good job on the keyboard. <br /> <br />Kashmir is propably the most famous song on the whole record, and for a good reason: it rocks! The lead riff is what a good riff should be, it's easily one of the best and most recognized in rock history. Though the song lasts 8 min.+, it won't let You down. It's an epic in itself and a rock anthem every rockfan knows. To sume it up, it's an amazing masterpiece. <br /> <br />In The Light opens the second disc of the album. This number starts with mysterious, almost haunted melody, and then turns into a dark rocker as the riff comes in. It's another epic that deserves attention. <br /> <br />Bron-Yr-Aur is short but sweet. It's an acoustic instrumental that never fails to please. The melody is beautiful and charming. Don't overlook this little gem! <br /> <br />Down By The Seaside is a mix of country, pop and blues. The ending result is pretty cool. The song is sweet and features great bluesy licks from Jimmy Page. It also has a rocking part in the middle that breaks the mood of the song well. Overall, it's another excellent track. <br /> <br />Ten Years Gone is sad, but inspired ballad. It has that dark feeling to it. One of the greatest tracks on the album. <br /> <br />Night Flight is a decent rock tune that is catchy in its own way, but sappy in the other way. Quite interesting, but You can pass it by. <br /> <br />The Wanton Song features a riff that is quite similar to that from Immigrant Song. It's another good rockin' tune, but also nothing that special. <br /> <br />Boogie With Stu is a funny blues jam. Always something good to listen to. Well, pretty cool song. <br /> <br />Black Country Woman is country tune with some good acoustic work from Mr. Page.  <br /> <br />Sick Again, a dark and powerful rocker, closes the album. This song is not as great as other rockers from the album, but it's pretty good and a nice closer. <br /> <br />Physical Grafitti, in my opinion, is not Led Zeppelin's strongest album. There are a FEW songs thatgive You the feeling of \\"filler\\" and could be cut, but for the most part, this album is satysfying. Of course it's not as catchy, shocky, straight in-your-face like let's say Led Zeppelin II, but it's still an excellent effort. If You're a Zepp fan, this is a must have, but if You're a new fan, I'd recommend Led Zeppelin II or ZOSO first. Come back to this record once You taste essential Zepp sound. <br /> <br />

0060934913|4.0|This book may not be for everyone; but, then, surprisingly, not everyone seems to get it.  Oddly enough, although the author seems to be quite experienced, hip, urbane, wordly and well... a \\"New York\\" chef; still, his book seems to ask the more experienced reader, \\"so what?\\"   <br /> <br />Where do we go from here?  I would give the author higher praise if he put behind the drama and got on to the next thing.  Affectations, no mater how naked or open, are not becoming. So although I give 4 stars, it is really a B or B-.  Perhaps his work is not quite finished.  (FYI: There is no A+ at chef school.) <br /> <br />It is ironic, that on occasion, Mr. Bourdain presents an occasional riddle in his memoir.  Its as if he questions what all his toil or success is all about. Yet, he doesn't go there, perhaps for fear of over intellectualizing.   After all that's contrary to the so-called work ethic of the kitchen, as he sees it.  Stick it out and just do it-- no matter what it takes. Or get out of the way.  That's his philosophy.  Or maybe that's not really it-- perhaps its insanity? <br /> <br />Well, I lived in New York for years. I expect anything and lived with everything.  I understand -- even studied--the French; i.e., culturally, historically, linguistically, etc.  I am a foodie myself.  I have grown up in food business, with generations of food business on my shoulders.  But I am Italian-American.  I am originally from Northern California. And so, I say, \\"So what!\\"  Been there, done that.  What's next? The last great American food revolution was, quite frankly, well beyond New York and all things French.  In fact, all things New York and French are almost dead now, in my opinion.  It been that way for decades.  Americans love Italian, Chinese and Mexican.  Go to any food convention or show, but also study our commercial culture, and then you will see that.  \\"Haute Cuisine\\" is only that.  There are West Coast trends that are equally tired, although Bourdain seems quiteclueless to them.   He makes no mention of it, except of a fleeting, admitedly ignorant California wine tasting.  The wine business is over-successful here and just as silly and pretentious as the French, with their fancy marketing nonsense. More, too, there are other tired \\"regional cuisines,\\" popular since the revolution of the 1980's gourmet movement. So, then, is this cutting edge or just postured attitude and ego?  I also share Bourdain's disdain for many celebrity chefs, but that does not say much, given all that.  They were already famous, when he was doing dope (no offense meant). <br /> <br />Bourdain is an engaging writer and I love his honest, brutal, stream of consciousness writing; but...  Did it occur to the author that there is a whole world out there, unlike NYC, unlike the French and unlike ego-maniac executive chefs.  And, said to what little he gives, there is indeed a thing called high-end, authentic Italian, unlike what he unflatteringly describes in his book.  There are so many ways of doing things.  Moreover, its been done!  Done to death!  There is lots of diversity out there and not everyone sees things the same way.  Ask what is good and what is right and you will get many opinions.  There are so many other people who make this industry, who call themselves, chefs, restuaranteurs, foodies, operators, owners, etc.  All of them are successful and/or failures.  This book is affirmation or fascination for some of them; and perhaps it is MUST reading for industry newbies; but, despite this book's honesty, it honestly is not all that honest.  A lot of it is indeed postured drama.  A lot of it is blindsighted bias and just plain full of itself.  Working with chefs, from inside or out of the kitchen, I'd say its very much Chef!, but there is more to being a foodie, than being just a French chef in New York City.  Attitude is nothing more than that.  Experience and insight, however, is another world beyond this.  Here's a taste... here's a place atthe table... now let's enjoy our food, be thankful for it and move on.  We have good food to eat and a lifestyle to live; but, after having said all that, and after being in the business for generations, I will tell you that its not simply a passion and choice for one over another.  Its a \\"simpatico,\\" for everone and everything and all things done.    <br /> <br />

Their time together is littered with adventures and misunderstandings, each one more outlandish than the one that preceeded it.<br /><br />And this is the very problem with \\"The Color of Magic\\".  There is so much movement between space and time and different lands and magic fields, that the readers as tourist get a little lost in the shuffle.  Terry Pratchett is a brilliant writer with an uncanny eye for the absurd and the book is filled with his trademark humor.  Even though I got a little lost on this voyage through Discworld, I look forward to reading more sagas about this land that is not too unlike our own.
