0393327655|2.0|A few quick thoughts: <br />1) A subject this large is far too complex for Harris' polemic. <br />2) The enlightenment critique of religion is a hardy perennial and has been done before and better by Voltaire & Bertrand Russell, among others.  Perhaps we need a contemporary reminder, but this is a shallow refreshment. <br />3) Read the sociologist-cum-historian Rodney Stark to get the other side of the story, i.e. some of the long term positive effects of Christianity in the West. <br />4) Harris cannot be a serious writer on this topic without referencing John Locke's \\"Letter Concerning Toleration\\". <br />5) Any polemic against religion in general that fails to acknowledge the 148,000,000 civilians murdered by communist regimes during the 20th century is intellectually lacking to the point of dishonesty.  Marxism was modern, rational, \\"scientific\\" according to its times, and explicitly atheistic.  Religion, that \\"opiate of the masses\\", looks pretty good by comparison. <br />6) Unless of course you argue that communism was harmful precisely to the extent that it became a secular religion itself -- which is called begging the premise. <br />7) I'm not sure who said that the only true sins are crimes against human nature, but it was a brilliant humanist insight. The need to believe in religion is part of human nature.  You cannot eradicate religion, nor is it reasonable to try.  You can perhaps gradually alter its doctrines, subordinate its place in the polity, and/or channel its effects within society, as recommended by Locke (the great thing about the separation of church and state).  <br />8) Regarding Islam in particular:  It is a theocracy that does not recognize the distinction between church and state.  Nor can Islam admit of Koranic criticism or reform, for the Koran is held to be the direct, immutable, and eternal word of Allah.  You can see the tensions between its origins and the modern world.  I can do no better than to quote Nietzsche from his essay \\"On the Advantage and Disadvantage of History for Life\\": <br /> <br />\\"A religion for example which, under the rule of pure justice, is to be transformed into historical knowledge, a religion which is to be known in a scientific way, will at the end of this path also be annihilated. The reason is that the historical audit always brings to light so much that is false, crude, inhuman, absurd, violent, that the attitude of pious illusion, in which alone all that wants to live can live, is necessarily dispelled: only with love, however, only surrounded by the shadow of the illusion of love, can man create, that is, only with an unconditional faith in something perfect and righteous. Each man who is forced no longer to love unconditionally has had the root of his strength cut off: he must wither, that is, become dishonest.\\"  <br /> <br />Nietzsche's observations are a problem for any believer, but Christianity has survived in a splintered and attenuated form because it has adapted historically, whereas Islam is less flexible and therefore in a crisis as it confronts modernity.  The shariah is all-encompassing.  I believe that many muslims are fearful of losing their culture under globalization in part because they intuit the truth of Nietzsche's criticism.  <br />
B00005JOII|4.0|In \\"Match Point,\\" Woody Allen, caught in one of his more \\"serious\\" moods, takes a simple tale about marital infidelity and turns it into something complex and fascinating.  Although he leaves a trail of clues implying that this is to be another of his homages to Fyodor Dostoevsky, the film really turns out to be Allen's own version of Theodore Dreiser's \\"An American Tragedy\\" (albeit set in England, perhaps to throw us off the scent). The parallels between the two works are not perfect, of course - in fact they often seem to be intentionally inverted - but they are close enough to make us wonder if Allen did, indeed, do it all on purpose.<br /><br />Jonathan Rhys-Meyers plays Chris Wilton, a down-on-his-luck social climber who marries into wealth but longs for the passion he finds with another woman.  Chris is a professional tennis player who decides to leave the circuit when he realizes he hasn't the skill to compete with the real pros.  Taking a job as an instructor at a posh, highly exclusive tennis club, Chris finds himself wining and dining with the rich and famous after one of his pupils, Tom Hewett, takes a liking to him and introduces Chris to his snooty but accepting family.  Chris begins to date Tom's warmhearted sister, Chloe, but he is really smitten by an aspiring American actress, Nola, who just happens to be Tom's fiance.  Chris makes the mistake of marrying Chloe before Tom and Nola call off their engagement and go their separate ways.  The fact that Nola is free but he is not doesn't deter Chris from pursing an affair with the woman who provides all the passion and excitement his loving but boring wife cannot.  But Chris soon discovers that carrying on an affair can result in a life filled with secrecy, lies, guilt and self-loathing.  And when the going gets to be just a bit too much for our hero to handle...well, there`s always that \\"final solution\\" lurking in the wings, as many an earlier adulterer has discovered to his everlasting regret.<br /><br />\\"Match Point\\" starts off very slowly and seems at first as if it will be just another tale of adultery and unrequited love.  Yet, Allen really knows how to draw us into Chris' predicament, so that, by about halfway into the film, we feel as enmeshed in his seemingly irreconcilable dilemma as he himself is.  Torn between the wealth and position he has as Chloe's husband and the love he feels for the relatively impoverished Nola, Chris is frozen into a state of paralyzing indecisiveness, his every waking moment a tormenting hell of fear and gathering dread as he keeps waiting in breathless anticipation for that other shoe to drop.  It isn't until the \\"other woman\\" becomes more of a burden than his clinging wife that Chris can finally launch into action.  This turnabout in the screenplay might strike many in the audience as arbitrary and implausible and there is certainly a case to be made for that.  But if you can go with the flow, you will be delighted by all the little ironies Allen throws at us in the final stages of the story, which help to underline the filmmaker's thesis that, for all the efforts we make to control our lives, The Fickle Finger of Fate - or in this case a tennis ball precariously balancing on the top of a net trying to figure out which way to fall - always has the final word.<br /><br />Allen has written dialogue that is incisive, intelligent and literate, and the performances he's drawn from the likes of  Rhys-Meyers, Goode, Emily Mortimer, Scarlett Johannson and Penelope Wilton are superb down to the tiniest detail.  Allen keeps his camera tightly focused on his characters, rarely pulling away from them much beyond a middle distance, keeping us firmly locked in the near-claustrophobic drama.  Here is a movie that demands patience at the beginning but that really sneaks up on you the longer you watch it.<br /><br />Guided by the hands of a master, \\"Match Point\\" is one of Allen's finest films in years.. <br /> <br />\\"Match Point\\" starts off very slowly and seems at first as if it will be just another tale of adultery and unrequited love.  Yet, Allen really knows how to draw us into Chris' predicament, so that, by about halfway into the film, we feel as enmeshed in his seemingly irreconcilable dilemma as he himself is.  Torn between the wealth and position he has as Chloe's husband and the love he feels for the relatively impoverished Nola, Chris is frozen into a state of paralyzing indecisiveness, his every waking moment a tormenting hell of fear and gathering dread as he keeps waiting in breathless anticipation for that other shoe to drop. B0006L0LOS|3.0|I admire the approach the filmmakers have taken towards \\"Catwoman,\\"  for rather than setting their tale in the same dark, cavernous, largely computer-generated metropolis we are used to in most of these superhero movies, they have chosen to keep it rooted more in the real world.  In a similar way, they manage to keep Catwoman herself believable, vulnerable and realistic, thanks in no small part to the beautiful and beguiling Halle Berry in the title role.<br /><br />Berry plays Patience Phillips, a pretty, but less-than-glamorous advertising artist who works for a major cosmetics company, ruled over by a tyrannical CEO and his equally ruthless wife, the former spokes model for their products.  When Patience mistakenly overhears the corporate bigwigs discussing the fact that one of their best-selling creams is causing women to become seriously ill, she is dutifully murdered by a couple of the boss' henchmen.  However, all is not lost for Patience, for, unbeknownst to her, she has been chosen to receive the special gift of reincarnation in the form of a cat woman who will no longer be subject to the laws of either nature or society.<br /><br />The best parts of \\"Catwoman\\" involve Patience's incrementally becoming more and more catlike in her attitude and demeanor, and her slowly dawning realization of what is happening to her.  It takes awhile for her to accept this surprising turn of events, but, when she does, she becomes, quite literally, a new woman, bold, self-confident and willing to take on the oppressors and evildoers in our society.  Patience is paired up with an attractive police officer (apparently the only one ever on duty in that city), who gradually comes to realize who and what she is as well.  Berry and Benjamin Bratt make a very appealing romantic couple, and their scenes together are some of the best in the movie.  Also impressive is Sharon Stone who deserves credit for allowing herself to appear in a role in which her \\"fading\\" beauty plays such a significant part (shades of Vivien Leigh playing Blanche DuBois in \\"A Streetcar Named Desire\\").  Stone is the villainous wife of the company's CEO who is determined to make sure Catwoman doesn't spill the beans on their defective product.<br /><br />The special effects are probably the least successful aspect of this film.  Catwoman's jumping from rooftop to rooftop looks an awful lot like CGI effects to me.  And the movie does occasionally go on auto pilot (especially towards the end), though, thankfully, not usually for very long.  The literal cat fight between Berry and Stone at the finale is necessary, I guess, but really rather silly overall.<br /><br />Still, considering the pounding this movie received from both critics and audiences when it was first released in the summer of 2004, I wound up being pleasantly surprised at just how enjoyable \\"Catwoman\\" turned out to be.beauty plays such a significant part (shades of Vivien Leigh playing Blanche DuBois in \\"A Streetcar Named Desire\\"). B0000035E7|4.0|I'm not gonna start to compare 'Bleach' too much to their later efforts, but try to concentrate on this one. <br />It's very clear that 'Bleach' is music made totally spontaneously in a short time, and without any expectations of getting famous (unlike 'Nevermind'). <br />I really sense that Kurt Cobain is very anxious and ambitious already here, and these songs are pure pictures of his mind. <br />Muddy guitars, that very well reflect Kurt's complex and crazy head (and the fact that he wasn't very talented player...)make it a very honest album. While most songs here are petty forgettable, some do standout, like the Beatles-like 'About a Girl' which also proves that Cobain had a great sense of pop and that his singing is far better than guitar playing, though his rhythm talents are okay. 'Blew' is another highlight, though it's a bit frustrating, it is Cobain's filtered pop-rage at its best. <br />'Negative Creep' pretty much speaks for itself, with very angsty lines like 'daddy's little girl ain't cure no more, I'm a negative creep and I'm stoned..(yes you are), so I guess the best thing with 'Bleach' is its honesty, it's no faking! <br />'Love Buzz', despite its nice riff is a pretty boring cover, but definitely a notable song however. The rest is pretty much average punk that might grab you for riff or two or a chorus here and there, but the songs don't stick in your head, nor show off any great talent from none of the members. Krist Novoselic is a good bassist, thouhg he doesn't stand out as much here as he did later. Dale Clover is also an okay drummer, though it wasn't till Dave Grohl joined, that they really got a dynamic drummer. <br />Jason Everman is supporting guitarist on the album, although he wasn't around for a long time, and nothing much I can say 'bout him. I think this record is pretty much the only 'grunge' album that Nirvana made, with its muddy and dark guitars and some wicked vocals going from softer to loud screaming. <br />Definitely for a Nirvana fan, but if you really consider 'Nevermind' to be like the best album you've heard ever, don't expect 'Bleach' to be anything near it! it's very different! there is no 'Smells Like Teen Spirit' or 'Lithium' on this one, well I give the record 4 stars, for being an interesting effort that is so much better than anything that's pop nowadays, and for the few songs like 'about a girl' & 'neagtive creep' , that were some of the best songs Cobain ever wrote. Worth to check out! but not a masterpiece!!

B000H30B2C|5.0|The original KING KONG is the movie that made Peter Jackson want to become a filmmaker. His whole life he's been wanting to make his own version of KONG. Ironically it was the box office pounding of THE FRIGHTENERS that allowed Jackson to make KING KONG: he was supposed to have made KING KONG after THE FRIGHTENERS, but since it did so bad, the studio said no. So, instead, Jackson did the incredible and made THE LORD OF THE RINGS instead, guaranteeing him that he would be able to make any movie he would ever want. Thus, Jackson's version of KING KONG was finally made.<br /><br />The plot goes something like this. Slimy filmmaker and showman Carl Denham gets into some trouble. To escape it and to make the movie of his dreams (catch Jackson's own self-mockery here) he hires a ship to take him to a mysterious island that only he has a map to: Skull Island. Sailors have long told stories about this mysterious island, but common folk have disregarded such talk as that of a drunk or mad man. But, Denham believes and sure enough, his belief leads his ship to Skull Island. There they find a somewhat cannibalistic group of islanders who kidnap the only female on the ship, Ann Darrow, and offer her up to their god, the gigantic gorilla King Kong. Kong takes their offering, but instead of destroying it, becomes fascinated by Darrow. In fact, Darrow's beauty enchants the great ape.<br /><br />But Kong isn't the only one who has fallen for Darrow's charms. Jack Driscoll is a semi-famous author who fell in love with Darrow during their trip at sea. Risking everything, Driscoll ventures deep into the jungle to rescue Ann and bring her back home. But Kong won't be separated from his person of affection and chases Driscoll. However, a trap has been set and Kong becomes trapped.<br /><br />He's then brought to New York and put on display. But Kong isn't a beast that can be tamed easily. He escapes his chained existence and finds the girl of his dreams. Unaccustomed to the urban jungle, Kong climbs to the one place he feels most at home--on top of the city's highest building. There he enjoys a few moments of peace with Darrow, before he faces off with a squadron of airplanes.<br /><br />KING KONG is a very impressive movie. Jackson does an extraordinary job of re-creating 1930s New York and to remaining faithful to the original spirit of the first KING KONG. However, at the same time he does so much more. Jackson's version of KING KONG does everything from turn a &#34;B&#34; movie into an &#34;A&#34; film to illustrate the class system that is developing in America, to satirize the extreme materialism and consumerism of our modern culture, to re-establish the classic everyman (Jack Driscoll as played by Adrian Brody) as a potential hero. The movie works on so many levels and has so much to say. At the same time, it is just a great movie.<br /><br />The film is a bit too long and the whole insect thing could have been cut (Even though it might be crucial to the Dante-esque journey Jackson was trying to display). Nevertheless, KING KONG is everything movies were meant to be. I wouldn't doubt that if 30 years from now another brilliant director comes along and says, &#34;When I saw Peter Jackson's KING KONG, I knew I wanted to make movies.&#34;, Kong climbs to the one place he feels most at home--on top of the city's highest building. There he enjoys a few moments of peace with Darrow, before he faces off with a squadron of airplanes.<br /><br />KING KONG is a very impressive movie. B0001XAPZ6|5.0|I first saw this anime when I was a pre-teen.  It was the first Japanese anime I ever saw.  I was absolutely captivated.  Now at age 27, I am still as captivated by it as the first time I saw it.  The first version I saw was the abridged English dubbed version.  I also had possession of the Japanese version but without subtitles.  Both were bootlegs and I watched them both several times (despite my inability to understand Japanese).  Before the Disney release hit the stores, a friend of mine found a boot leg copy of the Japanese version with English subtitles.  The subtitles were sloppy and inaccurate.  There was some dialogue that was never even translated.  However, with the understanding provided by the additional scenes in combination with a more accurate portrayal of dialogue than the English dub version, Nausicaa took on a whole new and deeper level of meaning and plot.   <br /> <br />I recently watched part of the Disney release with the modern dubbing.  I did not particularly care for the voice talent and acting.  Worse was the translations chosen for some of the dialogues.  Nausicaa, the main character, IS the ideal woman.  She is brave, strong, hopefull, compassionate, loving, gentle, intelligent, humble, and very human (she, despite being wonderful, has weaknesses just like everyone else).  I felt that the modern Disney English dialogue played down several of these strong virtues in Nausicaa's possession.  Being that her character is the central attraction of the movie, down playing these virtues is detrimental to the emotional impact of the movie. <br /> <br />Tonight, I just watched Nausicca on Turner Classic Movies (TCM).  They showed the film in the original Japanese dialogue with English subtitles.  This was not the same version as the boot leg that I already own.  The version the TCM showed was by far the best rendition that I have ever seen of Nausicaa.  Her inteligence shines in the dialogue, more so than any other version and her sweetness and humility are just a strong as the older English dubbed version.  I am not sure which edition TCM showed (perhaps it is the Disney release but with the viewing options of Japanese with English subs instead of English dubs?), but it was by far the most excellent rendition of the dialogue. <br /> <br />If you want the full impact of this wonderful story, the version shown on TCM is what you want to get.  Be sure to sacrifice English dialogue and read the English subtitles.  It is well worth it. <br /> <br />In the scope of all movies, animated or not, this is the movie that holds top place in my heart.  If you want a story synopsis, read some of the other excellently written reviews.  As for me, I will tell you that it is a wonderful and inspiring story.  Definitely a breath of fresh air in a world that is often gloomy and cynical.  It captivates the imagination, warms the heart, and just seems magical to watch.

0307276902|4.0|It's hardly news that an addict has a tenuous relation to the truth. What's more damaging about Frey's nonfiction masquerade is that others who need help will take seriously the author's \\"Will to Power\\" program of recovery. Testing the strength of one's will with a full glass of whiskey under the nose, as Frey claims to have done, isn't a recipe for lasting recovery for many people who are truly alcoholics or addicts.    The faith-based program that Frey rejects is NOT the only way to overcome addiction. But even major alternatives such as rational emotive therapy acknowledge that the addict must CHANGE to have decent odds of survival. I hope for Frey's sake that he avoids a return to addictive hell.    I stopped believing that A Million Little Pieces was a True Story a couple dozen pages into the book, as cliche characters and pat situations entered the story.  Still I found it a difficult book to put down. Frey's writing carries emotional heft, and his slapdash style well conveys the urgency of a young addict.     I plan to read his second book. I won't recommend his stuff as a blueprint for anyone else's life. I recommend A Million Little Pieces for anyone who has a couple hours to kill and an interest in what takes place in a treatment center for addiction.

0307276902|5.0|While the marketing of this material as \\"memoir\\" and \\"nonfiction\\" may be confounding to some in light of recent \\"revelations\\" (and Frey does not hold the major responsibility for choosing how to classify it, his publisher does), most of the self-proclaimed critics who now base their observations and, in some cases, even reverse their original assessments of this work, seeking to dismiss Frey's talent, really reflect most negatively upon themselves.  Frey is irrefutably a major talent.  The merit of a work, whether fictional or not, lies in the degree of truth that resonates through it and how vibrantly that truth is conveyed.  In literature, as well as in all art forms, \\"truth\\" is not to be confused with \\"fact\\".  This isn't journalism; Frey's tale doesn't break with truth for an instant, regardless of the degree to which it's factual, and that is the ultimate basis for determining the merit of any work of art.  This book will forever reside among my favorite hardback volumes on my bookshelf, and I am grateful to have discovered it.
0307276902|1.0|I actually finished this book about 2 weeks ago.  Sorry to jump on the band wagon this late in the game.  I work in the addictions field. While reading this book, I never comtemplated the author's legal issues as being truthful or untruthful. I did however, find his story of his treatment to be quite unbelievable. First, what rang false for me was the author's depiction of the emergency dental care under the watchful eye of the unnamed treatment facility we know now to be Hazelden.  As an addictions' treatment professional with 20 years experience, I cannot for the life of me fathom why a dentist was prohibited from using novacaine to treat some serious injuries and HOW a dentist agreed to that.  What treatment center would make that a condition of allowing their patients to receive adequate dental care? Novacaine is NOT addictive.  It is not mood-altering.  It is not, as some would believe, related to cocaine.  Second:  Hazelden has the reputation of being a pretty expensive facility which offers good, thorough treatment.  According to Mr. Frey's book, there was a sorry lack of true treatment professionals coupled with a lack of structure.  There are scenes depicted in the book when counselors felt free to share private patient information with the other patients (a violation of a federal law, by the way). This facility was apparantly a place where patients were allowed to have private, catered parties, leave the facility frequently for romantic trysts, and go on rescue missions to the local crack house (accompanied by Hazelden staff !!???).  All with staff knowledge.  Sorry, that just didn't happen.<br /><br />I understand that ALL treatment programs are flawed.  It is a fact of life and a factor in helping addicts to receive adequate help.<br /><br />Finally,don't even get me started on the encounter in France with the priest. 0307276902|5.0|James Frey is a brilliant writer who has the misfortune of being a little less wicked than he portrayed himself in his memoir. Admittedly he used literary license when describing the extent of his law-breaking.  He was a rich frat rat, for God's sake.  But just because his worst offenses consisted of binges that lasted for months, broken promises, a cowering family, police breathing down his neck, vomit-covered bathrooms, severe acne, missed classes, nightmare exams (with no advance study buddies) and no future to speak of doesn't mean he didn't feel totally demoralized when he hit rock bottom.  So what if the feds weren't waiting to send him up the river for 100 years -- it could have felt that way to him at the time.      Personally as a woman I couldn't relate to the train wreck story,  the REAL reason that his one true love left him, etc etc. It all seemed a bit too over the top. But I'm not a great writer.  Maybe I wouldn't have found the book quite as mesmerizing if his prior offenses weren't so serious and horrendously guilt-inducing and if the legal threat looming over him weren't so serious.    But to get back to the title of my review -- give the guy a break.  Let's pat him on the back for not being such a bad guy after all.  And -- Smoking Gun -- I don't want to hear from you again unless you catch Jim Frey hitting the bottle (or shooting up) because that would be a story (an unfortunate and sad one) -- not your petty unravelings of the TRUTH.

0312995423|3.0|Dan Brown is three for three with me (I've yet to read Deception Point). What Dan does well, he does VERY well. His plots are tight and maticulousely well designed. He textures his stories with intriguing, almost unnecassary details which yet prove contrary to that assumption and eventually prove crutial to the plot. For example, he'll educate the reader on the root meaning of a particular word which then ties into the plot in some crutial way. Everything is plot driven, and the stakes are always at their peak. It is his ploting skills and masterful stakes building that attract so many readers.<br /><br />However, though his plotting has proven successful, he has followed the same plot skeleton in each of the three books I've read. This may play well for many readers who enjoy the familiarity of the same well-traveled paths. For this adventurer, though, I prefer to travel new trails, or at least trails disguised well enough that they feel new. I also noticed with this particular plot that a few of the subplots were drawn out far too much in order to keep pace with the main plot. And, as with any author who writes plot- and stakes-heavy stories, a reader who is seeking an intimate relationship with the characters and the sense of being lost in emotionally rich language will likley be disappointed.<br /><br />That said, most warm-blooded readers will enjoy this tale like the rest of Brown's thrillers. What he does well is done so well we forgive him the rest and are waiting patiently for the next dose of adrenaline.
0553801503|3.0|After reading some of the reviews that compared this book to the demise in writing that happened with Robert Jordan's Wheel of Time series, I was almost afraid to crack the cover.  For anyone that has managed to keep up with Jordan's fated series, you have a good idea of just how bad writing can get, and just how low a once good series can fall.  In fact, I would say that book 10 of the Wheel of Time series is probably the worst book that I have ever read (fiction or non-fiction). <br /> <br />Fortunately, having just finished \\"A Feast for Crows\\", I can say that although the book is not on the same level as the first 3 books of the series, it is still an OK read.  I enjoyed the first 3 books so much that I pre-ordered this one before it could be reviewed.  I will not make that mistake again.  I would advise getting a copy form the local library unless you need it for your collection.  I don't think we should reward the writer and publisher for less than quality work.  Having said that, Martin is a very good writer (several levels above Robert Jordan), and even one of his poorer works is an entertaining and worthwhile read. <br /> <br />Of course, as Martin points out in the end of the book some characters are left out of this book, because he felt it would be better to \\"tell the entire story for half the characters, rather than tell half the story for all the characters\\".  But, isn't telling part of the story for all the characters exactly what he has been doing in the first 3 books?  Doesn't that really define what a series is about?  The whole story is not complete until the last book.  It is very hard to pick up on a character that is completely skipped in one book, and that you don't hear from for 2-5 years.   <br /> <br />Some of the characters that were covered in this book were \\"over cooked\\".  Many of these pages could have been spared to keep us up to date with those not covered.  I liked Brienne, the girl knight in the other books, but we had to follow heraround through so many useless ramblings in this book that by the end I was hoping she could just die a valiant death and be finished.  I also got very sick of Cersei.  She got way too much press in this book.  I think that Martin had managed to establish Cersei as a self-centered, self-serving, evil bitch in the other books.  That image was beaten to death in this book.  In addition, Martin also made Cersei an insane drunkard, just in case we needed some extra ammunition to hate her.  I got to the point that I dreaded seeing her name on the chapter heading.  I knew that it would just be more of her scheming, evil plans, and stupid political moves.  Many of Cersei's schemes never seemed to go anywhere, but just filled page after page after page.  At least Cersei's last chapter was satisfying. <br /> <br />Too many pages seemed to go to establishing characters that were already well established, without advancing the story line.  In fact, the story seemed to get side-tracked in this book, and ended up meandering around, but not getting very far.   <br /> <br />If this book were a pie, you would find that the crust (Cersei, Brienne, etc.,) to be burnt, while the center of the pie (Arya, Jon, etc.) was under-cooked and still cold.  If you taste the pie you find that the cook has forgotten some of the key ingredients in the recipe (Tyrion, Dany, etc.).  You can eat a slice, but you will not desire seconds. <br /> <br />I read that Martin originally planned for this series to be 3 books.  That number grew to 4, then 6, and now I have heard that it will take at least 7 to finish it.  If the next book is anything like this one, seven may be a conservative number. <br />

At times it's barely coherent, and story quality fluctuates between fabulous and barely readable. The first (and last) visited story is arguably the dullest, even though plot wise it showed great potential. The only thing I could really say I enjoyed about it was the depth of period detail employed. The next story we are invited into was much more exiting, and enjoyable, to read. The third, 'Half Lives, the First Luisa Rey Mystery' was my personal favorite segment of the novel, it was exiting, interesting and like a mystery novel. Sadly from then on it was all a downhill ride, though Sloosha's Crossing and Evrything After' picked up from time to time. <br /> <br />I think the real problem with this novel, for me at least, was the lack of connections between the stories, it struck me as odd that these seven self contained worlds should even be part of the same novel. It seemed that Mitchell had been unable to decidce which idea to novelize, and had simply chosen to include all of them, which could have worked brilliantly had the stories fitted together better. Reading 'Cloud Atlas' was akin to reading a collection of short stories. And by the time each tale had you intrigued it would be over, and you'd have to start again with a different one. I think this book deserves five stars for beauty of description, use of language and clever characterization, but the plot messed me around so much I can only grudgingl give it three stars, which is a pity, because I think Mitchell's writing is generally brilliant and one of his other novels, 'Number9Dream', is probably one of the most enjoyable books I've read to date.

B000002J0G|5.0|I've been aware of Testament since their very beginning and I'm agree with almost everyone that their three (or perhaps four?) first releases are all classics. Also, no doubt about the skills of Alex Scholnick, who arguably was (IS, after the recent reunion) the main attraction of this band. However, in spite of all that, I have terribly felt in love with \\"Low\\" and now it is my preferred Testament album. But... why? <br /> <br />Well, perhaps the first thing to notice is the sharp production. Killer sound, you find no better in the Testament's catalogue! Other element would be the downtuned guitars. They give a darker feeling to their music. The death metal influences integrate well with the proggish edge Testament always had, and still the final product sounds coherent and very solid from the songwriting point of view. Additionally, Chuck Billy shows some new vocal influences, which is far from being disappointing. In fact, the more divergent from the Bay Area archetypical voice his vocals are, the more I like him!  <br /> <br />Some words now dedicated to the amazing shredder James Murphy is. I must confess that he was almost unknown to me when I picked this album up. I must say now: for those of you who are worrying about the absence of Alex Scholnick (like I was too), I can safely tell you that James Murphy is an axeman of the same calibre. \\"Low\\" is a safe buy for sure, but an even safer one if all you want is a shredding guitar fest. His work on the superb ballad \\"Trail Of Tears\\" is of the finest around, but every guitar riff and solo on this album finds the perfect balance between taste, spontaneity and technicality -- that's guaranteed! I dare to say: even if you loved Scholnick I don't think you'll miss him here! <br /> <br />So, this album has changed it all for me. Before \\"Low\\" I thought Annihilator had produced the two most magical thrash masterpieces ever (\\"Alison Hell\\" and \\"Never Neverland\\"), but now \\"Low\\" has also entered in my own temple of sacred metal records. \\"Low\\" maybe is slightly less progressive, but it has a lot of \\"charm\\" -- that weird impalpable thing emanating from true works of art! In few words, if you are looking for a greatly-produced, written and performed thrash metal opus with all the heavy ingredients you wanted, from growling vocals to a true blast of GREAT guitar riffs, solos and power drumming, search no more: this is it! FIVE freakin' BIG stars!

I think it is missplaced in a disc like this.  Yet, there is something for everyone. Not one of my favorites. <br /> <br />11.- Hot Tequila Brown sounds a lot like Electric Mistress, it's simply addictive in the long term. <br /> <br />12.- Time Won't Wait is a great way to finish the album off. 0743243315|1.0|I have read \\"Brick Lane\\", by Monica Ali, over a period of two and a half months. We had to read it in school, so we concerned ourself intensively with this book. Every time I started reading the book I had to stop myself from yawning! <br /> <br />This book is about a Muslim woman from Bangladesh, called Nazneen, who is forced to marry a 40-year old man, named Chanu, at the age of 18. When Nazneen was born everybody thought that she would die except her mother who believed that if fate decided her daughter should live, then she would live. Nazneen survives and this is the reason why she accepts everything that happens to her instead of fighting against her fate. <br />After the marriage both live together in a small flat in Tower Hamlets in London. Nazneen always misses her younger sister, Hasina, who lives in Dhaka. In contrast to Nazneen Hasina does not believe that her fate is already sealed. In her opinion her fate lies in her own hands. While Nazneen lives in London with her kind and educated husband, who does not beat her. Hasina has a horrible life in Dhaka. <br />Nazneen envies her younger sister a little because she takes responsibility for her own life. <br />Although Nazneen knows that she is not allowed to have an affair, she starts one with a younger man, she does not really love. <br />During their life in London Chanu has to suffer some defeats, so that he thinks that it is the best idea for his family to go back to Bangladesh. At this moment Nazneen realizes that she has to act in a responsible manner and tell her husband that he is the only one who goes back to Bangladesh, because Nazneen as well as her daughters would be unhappy in Dhaka. <br />Finally, Nazneen stays in London with her children and works in a fashion factory of one of her friends. Her husband has moved to Dhaka and her affair has also ended. On the whole, Nazneen seems to be really happy when she takes control of her life. <br /> <br />All in all, I am totally surprised that this book is a \\"Sunday Times\\" bestseller because, in my opinion, their is nothing special about Monica Ali's work. It is just boring! <br />The story is introduced by Nazneen's birth and how she is left to her fate. Although it is a nice idea to start a novel with a flashback, it is actually pretty boring because of the way it is written, in other words she uses a lot of description that makes the book uninteresting, and the topic \\"fate\\" does not belong to any important issues like poverty, unemployment, etc. A topic that relates to one of them might have been more interesting. During the whole novel you are reminded by almost every event that Nazneen was left to her fate. On the one hand, you can say that the characters have a personality development, but on the other hand it is not a big one and after a few pages you realize that it is always the same, so that you are not interested in reading the book any more. <br />I think specially Chanu, who always teaches Nazneen, Mrs.Islam, who crave for money, and the self-pitying Dr.Azad are boring. They show the same behavioural pattern until nearly the end of the novel and then their personalities change from one moment to the next. It is so taxing to try to remember anything about them. Another annoying aspect is the way it is structured, e.g. by Hasina's letters. Although I know that her English is not better than Nazneen's English, which is actually really bad, I am surprised that her letters are written in bad English instead of perfect English. It might have been more pleasant to read and as a matter of fact it wouldn't have changed anything, because they would have written each other the letters in their own language. As a result it is more difficult to concentrate on reading them, so that you are soon on bad terms with thebook in general. <br /> <br />You can describe this book with just one word: BORING!!!

0440418569|2.0|The final volume of the His Dark Materials trilogy pales in comparison to the first two books.  It seems as if Pullman could have pulled the series out into more than just a trilogy.  The Amber Spyglass is full of many questions and many solutions to the questions put forth earlier on, but as you finish the book, it feels like Pullman really had to rush and squeeze all the answers into the 518 pages of the novel.  For one thing, the novel tries to closely follow too many characters' storylines.  Lyra and Will's journey is obviously the most important, but their story shares equal time with the stories of Lord Asriel and Mrs. Coulter (Lyra's parents), and the totally uninteresting, weird, confusing story of Mary Malone and her encounter with a race of animals called the mulefa in a different world.<br /><br />Also, for me personally, the entire undertone of the book (and trilogy, really) was just a little too disconcerting.  Granted, I am a Christian, but normally I have no problem reading books or watching movies that don't agree with me spiritually.  But I can't remember reading or seeing anything that was so blatantly hateful of religion in general.<br /><br />As opposed to other fantasy series, His Dark Materials never really sets a \\"good vs. evil\\" conflict.  I'm sure some people like it that way, but I prefer having a side to root for in a novel about epic conflicts, and there was no side for me to identify with here.<br /><br />I went into this trilogy with high expectations, hearing that it rivaled LOTR in epic status, and I leave the trilogy very disappointed.  The first two novels are both exceptional, but the final volume, in my opinion, brings down the entire trilogy with rushed, convoluted ending.

0307276902|1.0|Like most readers I was deeply moved by James Frey's account of his redemption of soul and recovery from drug and alcohol addiction, but with the recent unveiling of blatant fabrication in the book I can no longer accept to book for having any level of credibility.  I remain touched by the possibility that the story could have taken place, the broken lives represented most certainly exist in the world every day, however the book is fiction inspired by acutual events.  To examine how deep this problem goes consider this example: since Frey didn't commit the crimes he claims he did and was not facing years in prison how deep could his relationship actually have been with \\"Miles\\" and \\"Leonard\\"?  Neither of them obviously could have \\"pulled any strings\\" to help him out since he wasn't in any trouble to begin with.  Since the prison episode is a lie maybe Leonard never confronted James out in the rain when he was on the edge of leaving the clinic either let alone the \\"this is my new son\\" godfather-esque parting at the end of the book.  Forget about the whole event of nearly killing the Priest in Paris, that smacked of hyperbole even when I believed the story.  Most sadly I have lost confidence in the reality of James and Lilly's love affair and especially his act of her rescue.  I do not mean to say that what James Frey accomplished by rebuilding his life is trite or unworthy of praise or even that the book he wrote is without power.  I simply believe that there is an expectation that even though this is a memoire that blatant lies will not be fed to me as a reader.  I believed in James Frey, but now I only wish he had labeled his book a novel because there would have been no betrayal of trust.

The album that launched the diva from New Jersey is a absolute standard of records from the 1980's, and a treat from the days of MTV. The album includes so many beautiful pop melodies that truly have withstood the test of time like the #1 smashes Saving All My Love For You, her first track to chart, You Give Good Love, the beautiful Greatest Love Of Them All, All At Once, and the upbeat dance track How Will I Know. The songs here still sound great after all this time, and are just great guilty pleasure melodies that can't be resisted to this day.<br /><br />If you don't own a Whitney Houston record, than her debut album would be a great buy for anybody who still enjoys her music after all this time, or anybody who isn't too familiar with her legendary songs. B000BW7QWW|4.0|After having sat through the series, which I ended up being rather indifferent towards, I decided that I had to see how it ended, so I got myself a copy of this. It was definitely the right decision.    There wasn't much Western in sight at all, in _Serenity_, (which was my problem with the original series); it was nearly pure sci-fi, which I truly enjoyed. Finally we have an answer to the problem of River, we see how Simon rescued her and what it is the Alliance is afraid she knows. We finally know where Reavers come from! That alone was pretty awesome.    There were some good surprises thrown at us, things I never saw coming, and one that actually brought a tear to my eye, even when I really hadn't cared much about the characters in the series. The action is good, there's plenty of suspense and you really aren't sure, even in the end, if they're going to win or not.    Granted, the wrap up of that felt a little...forced, to me, a bit on the dues ex machina end of things, but it was still satisfying. I don't think I would've preferred that they all go out in some sort of _Butch and Sundance_ sort of way. That wouldn't have felt right; I might not be a hundred percent comfortable with how this was resolved, but neither was it bad. Not completely believable, but not totally beyond the realms of belief, either. Not too bad of a mix.    This movie does a pretty good job of wrapping up the series while still giving just a hint of leeway for a sequel, or even a second chance at another series. I don't see that happening, not with the networks having their heads stuck in places where sunlight is rare, but stranger things have happened and Joss has shown that he can pull off minor miracles before.

0684824906|5.0|Doris Kearns Goodwin has rapped out a gem of a book that has added greatly to our knowledge of Abraham Lincoln and his times. This book by this woman is indeed a sacred effort, and the black abolitionist Frederick Douglass could not have had more appreciation for Lincoln's second inaugural address than I did for Ms. Goodwin Kearns' latest contribution. <br /> <br />By focusing on four men, with Lincoln in center ring, Kearns Goodwin is able to view Lincoln and the issues of his times from multiple perspectives. In comparison of my knowledge of Lincoln, I knew little of Salmon Chase, William Seward and Edward Bates, Lincoln's major rivals for the 1860 presidential nomination of the fledgling Republican Party and who Lincoln cleverly appointed as members of his Presidential cabinet. The narrative of \\"Team of Rivals\\" shows how Chase, Seward and Bates grew during their time with Lincoln, or, in Chase's case, grew unevenly. Lincoln and Seward especially, became brothers in time.  <br /> <br />I also enjoyed obtaining new knowledge of the rolling temperament of Edward Stanton, Lincoln's hard Attorney General. Kearns Goodwin employs \\"Lincoln's Neptune\\" Gideon Welles as a sort of court jester, who pops in and out of her story to draw out different elements of Lincoln's character; many are playful and amusing.  <br /> <br />Mary Todd Lincoln is treated with dignity and feeling, and when Lincoln finished his life, his finish was not overwritten and glorified into some kind of dark romantic act, as political assassinations often are. That was mature restraint on the part of the author. By choosing that path, Kearns Goodwin focused on the special light that was the life of the backwoods, self-educated rail splitter. <br /> <br />Ms. Kearns Goodwin dedicated this book to her husband, Richard Goodwin. She is deeply in love.

B000002UJQ|5.0|If you know anything about the history of our current state in the music industry, then you probably know about \\"OK Computer\\"'s influence. What they did, essentially, was implement electronics into their anthemic rock sound which made it \\"ok\\" (get it) for such a move to even take place (after all, this came out in 1997). This wasn't just a gimmick, however - every song here is good-if-not-amazing. Most people only know their classic hit \\"Paranoid Android\\", but the rest are just as good, creative and inspired as this song (though it *might* take some time to like the others as they aren't as instantly catchy and memorable most of the time). Musically the album sounds relatively similar to \\"The Bends\\", but, like I said, with an electronic element added to it - this is where the name of the album factors in. The lyrics are always interesting to listen to, even if they're not necessarily memorable or decipherable some of the time. They're essentially about finding beauty in a world of seemingly unnatural things (aka technology). Singer Thom Yorke has such incredible energy, personality and charm that it would be almost impossible not to love him. He's definitely a unique-sounding singer who can take the emotion of the lyrics and musicianship that much further with any song in which he sings. I'm pretty confident that most people in this world will enjoy him. Basically, if you're a Radiohead fan or if you're looking for music that will remain interesting and fun forever then \\"OK Computer\\" is a great purchase! Absolutely recommended!<br /><br />Highlights include:<br />the entire album!

0679409998|3.0|Mary Shelley was born in London in 1797, two years before the death of George Washington.  She wrote \\"Frankenstein\\" when she was 19 or 20, depending on which literary historian you choose to believe.  If you approach this novel as the work of a teenager in the England of two centuries ago, it is impressive.  If you treat it as a piece of literature, it is absolutely awful.  As many other readers have pointed out, the basic story idea is great but it is very badly written.  Shelley's language is flowery to the point of absurdity.  She might be allowed to get away with wildly overwritten dialogue, considering the period in which the book was written, but just try to imagine the nine-foot tall hideous monster, who has deliberately murdered a small child, speaking these lines: \\"I soon perceived that although the stranger uttered articulate sounds and appeared to have a language of her own, she was neither understood by, nor herself understood, the cottagers.  They made many signs which I did not comprehend, but I saw that her presence diffused gladness through the cottage, dispelling their sorrow as the sun dissipates the morning mists.\\"  The plot, too, has some seriously nonsensical elements, the most basic of which may be Victor Frankenstein simply walking away from his newly created monster.  The creation of the monster, incidentally, is not described.  All of the lightening-catchers and pseudoscientific gadgetry was the invention of later dramatists.  Mary Shelley's achievement was to create the Frankenstein myth, which has been dramatized and parodied repeatedly.  Despite the glaring faults of her novel, \\"Frankenstein\\" is historically important, and the story itself does have some genuinely interesting episodes.  The edition published by Everyman's Library is inexpensive, nicely printed and bound, and has an excellent introduction by Wendy Lesser.  Shelley's early life, as described by Lesser, was so bizarre and socially irresponsible that it would make a good subject for a historical novel.  \\"Mother of Frankenstein\\"?ect for a historical novel.  \\"Mother of Frankenstein\\"?
B0000025H0|5.0|As my title suggests I have 'ripped' this CD--as well as several thousand--of my three thousand CD collection onto my iPod and have revisited many of the older albums that I had put into storage cases. I have always thought this CD was a fantastic one and repeated listening to it via the iPod has affirmed it.<br /><br />The title track warns one and all, that the remainder of the album is going to be a long running sprint. The music is fine. This is latin rock--or rock at its finest form; lyrical, driving and melodic.<br /><br />\\"Aqua Marine\\" describes melodically the comparitive imbue of blue and green: imagine the ocean and the waves.<br /><br />\\"Stay (Beside Me)\\" is sung by Alex Ligertwood (dang I miss his vocals), a vocal track with emblazoned Santana licks.<br /><br />\\"Hard Times\\" is an anthem dedicated to positivity.<br /><br />\\"Love\\" is asking--pleading actually--for change.<br /><br />The music beckons endurance--the verb is the vibe--pay attention, the competition is fierce.
1592400876|5.0|I think this book was written especially for me! I have always been a \\"stickler\\" for grammar, spelling and punctuation, much to the dismay of my schoolmates and even the occasional teacher who dared to misspell a word on the chalkboard. I have even corrected signs at Wal-Mart: \\"For Safety Sake\\" changed to \\"For Safety's Sake\\" with a handy black Sharpie. I can even point you to a permanent inspection sign over a fire extinguisher where I added a much-needed apostrophe. <br /> <br />In Lynne Truss's own words: <br />\\"For any true stickler, you see, the sight of the plural word \\"Book's\\" with an apostrophe in it will trigger a ghastly emotional process similar to the stages of bereavement, though greatly accelerated. First there is shock. Within seconds, shock gives way to disbelief, disbelief to pain, and pain to anger. Finally (and this is where the analogy breaks down), anger gives way to a righteous urge to perpetrate an act of criminal damage with the aid of a permanent marker.\\" <br /> <br />I keep a permanent marker in my purse at all times. <br /> <br />Throughout the book, Ms. Truss touches upon the accepted uses for multiple forms of punctuation, as well as their grotesque misuses. She often quotes noted writers, such as George Bernard Shaw, Gertrude Stein, James Thurber, and Mark Twain, and has a seemingly unending supply of colourful, humourous anecdotes and quotes to illustrate her points (no pun intended).  <br /> <br />In another passage, Truss writes what could be a dust-jacket summary for a grammarian's mystery book: <br />\\"Yes, you can see the bullet points here, here and here, sir; there are multiple back-slashes, of course. And that's a forward slash. I would have to call this a frenzied attack. Did anyone hear the interrobang?\\" <br />\\"Oh, yes. Woman next door was temporarily deafened by it. What's this?\\" <br />\\"Ah. You don't see many of these anymore. It's an emoticon. Hold your head this way and it appears to be winking.\\" <br />\\"Good God! You mean -?\\" <br />\\"That's the mouth.\\" <br />\\"You mean - ?\\" <br />\\"That's the nose.\\" <br />\\"Good grief. Then it's -?\\" <br />\\"Oh, yes, sir. There's no doubt about it, sir. The punctuation murderer has struck again.\\" <br /> <br />It was a truly delightful read, and I recommend it to anyone who has ever winced at a poorly punctuated passage. :-)

The epilogue was of course, the best part of the book.<br /><br />Love, Rosie is written in a way that has become more popular in recent years. It's written in form of e-mails,IMing, letters, and cards. Readers of Meg Cabot's adult books will be familiar with this format. This format is one of those things where you either love it or you hate it. It's hard to be indifferent about the style. I personally like the style and it doesn't bug me in the slightest. But if you don't like the format of a book written entire in e-mails and letters then you have been warned.<br /><br />But the story of Rosie and Alex is truly a great one and hopefully everyone will like it as much as I have.

0553212443|4.0|Every Christmas I say I will reread A Christmas Carol, by Charles Dickens, and this past Christmas I actually did it. <br /> <br />Nobody needs reminding of the story of A Christmas Carol.  We all know the tale of Scrooge and his visits by the Ghost of Christmas Present, the Ghost of Christmas Past and the Ghost of Christmas Future.  Even for those who have never read the book, the story has been retold in many different forms and at least three versions make their appearance on our television screens each Christmas. <br /> <br />So why has this little tale proved to be so popular?  I think it's because Scrooge is such a memorable character and we all know someone we like to think of as a Scrooge.  And, let's be honest, we would like them to change.  A Christmas Carol touches the desires of all of us to show people what they are really like and have them change for the better.  And Scrooge is also one of those characters that seem to be likeable even when they're easy to dislike. <br /> <br />I think this book is still worth reading, even though we know the story.  It is a very small book.  I read it in its entirety on Christmas Eve.  It is also very easy to read.  Some classics, I feel, are difficult for the modern reader because our tastes and expectations are different from those of the past.  But because A Christmas Carol was written quickly by Dickens, and kept short, it will pose no problems to readers of today. <br /> <br />Besides being a great tale, A Christmas Carol also gives us an insight into the way Christmas was celebrated in Victorian society.  Don't wait until Christmas to read it! <br />

Lends good insight into how some companies could use some really simple principles to steer clear of mediocrity & rose a great deal...<br /><br />Simple principles - as it turns out - arent all that simple to put to practice. And that is what causes some good companies to remain good forever - while others rise.<br /><br />Quite many reviewers have harped on the fact that most of the companies studied to have risen to great levels have - since then - not been all that great. well, i dont think that is a problem with this book. B00005JNEI|2.0|For the individual who is well read and keeps up with current events, much of the content on this DVD will not come as a surprise. Moore's documentary argues that the Bush administration not only handled the terrorist attacks on the WTC and the Pentagon in an incompetent manner but that George W. Bush along with members of his family had ties with the individuals who were either directly or indirectly responsible for the 9/11 attacks. The film opens with the aftermath of the 2000 elections and moves on from there. Moore rehashes much of what was already reported on such as Dr. Rice's ignorance regarding the report on Bin Laden submitted to her a month before the attacks. He also rehashes former counterterrorism czar Richard Clarke's interview on Good Morning America, after he quit his job, where Clarke elaborates on how the Bush administration was obsessed with linking Iraq and al-Qaida together when in fact no such link ever existed. There are some entertaining parts of the film such as the former phone worker who was questioned by the FBI at his apartment after calling Bush a derogatory name at his local gym which was overheard by another gym member. With the exception of the revelation of Bush's relationship to James R. Bath, much of this won't come as a surprise. If one wants a better in depth look into the 9/11 attacks I recommend picking up a copy of House of Bush-House of Saud by Craig Unger, Superpatriotism by Michael Parenti, and Forbidden Truth (two French authors) which elaborates in detail the U.S. government's early diplomatic relationship with the Taliban regarding establishing a pipeline. Also PBS Frontline put out two excellent specials, which may not be on DVD yet, entitled House of Saud (history of the U.S.--Saudi relationship up to 9/11) and The Man Who Knew which is the story of the late FBI agent John O'Neill and his attempts to foil the 9/11 attacks only to fail due in part to diplomatic red tape and an apathetic U.S. government.
0307276902|2.0|From the Merriam Webster Dictionary: <br /> <br />embellish:  transitive verb <br />1 : to make beautiful with ornamentation : decorate <br />2 : to heighten the attractiveness of by adding ornamental details : enhance <br /> <br />dramatize: verb <br />1 : to adapt (as a novel) for theatrical presentation <br />2 : to present or represent in a dramatic manner <br /> <br />fabricate:  transitive verb <br />1 a : invent, create b : to make up for the purpose of deception <br />2 : construct, manufacture; specifically : to construct from diverse and usually standardized parts <br /> <br />fiction: noun <br />1 a : something invented by the imagination or feigned; specifically : an invented story b : fictitious literature (as novels or short stories) c : a work of fiction; especially : NOVEL <br />2 a : an assumption of a possibility as a fact irrespective of the question of its truth &lt;a legal fiction> b : a useful illusion or pretense <br />3 : the action of feigning or of creating with the imagination <br /> <br />lie: verb <br />1 : to make an untrue statement with intent to deceive <br />2 : to create a false or misleading impression <br /> <br />Dramatization and embellishment are a necessary part of memoir writing. However, while Frey does certainly dramatize and embellish numerous parts of his book, he clearly goes far beyond that as well. There is no definition of embellishment that allows for turning a traffic ticket into three months of hard time in prison; when you take a tragedy that you have only heard about and write that you had been a key player in its unfolding, you have gone beyond dramatization. Both these, and numerous other examples, are fabrications and fictions. Plain and simple. If we, as a culture lose the distinction in our literature between embellishment and complete fabrication, then we lose the distinction between fiction and non-fiction altogether. Let Frey call his words what they are, and have them judged accordingly. Thus farhe has not done this. He has admitted to embellishment only, and that is neither fiction nor fabrication nor embellishment nor dramatization. It is a lie.  <br />

There is a lot on here that didnt make it into the film (at least that I remember) and you dont have to have seen the film to enjoy the music. But what are you waiting for? See it!
B000E1ZBGS|5.0|I love Jane Austen, but I am not a purist when it comes to any movie adaptation of a book. The book is always better; that is a given. The films based upon it strive to deserve its title. Cinema and literature are two very different forms of creative expression, and I believe that it is impossible for any film to completely capture Austen's genius of Pride and Prejudice. Yes, the BBC miniseries was excellent. This film is better. By not trying to \\"be\\" the book, but \\"be\\" the characters, this version of Pride and Prejudice brings new emotions that the BBC miniseries missed. I was never swept away by the miniseries; I love it, but it did not make me wish to be Lizzy, as the novel, and now this wonderful film, does. The director and actors portrayed the Pride and Prejudice of my imagination, and I can offer no higher praise than that.

1591840562|3.0|This is not a manual, but rather a collection of mostly useful tips for people who wish to start businesses, or even, as author Guy Kawasaki claims, other sorts of projects, including nonprofit organizations. Kawasaki may overuse business-babble such as \\"bootstrapping\\" or \\"rainmaking\\" (in fact, he recommends coming up with a brand name that can enter the language as a verb, such as Google or Xerox) - but his style is good-natured and humorous. The chapters are divided accessibly with subheads, charts, bullet points, \\"minichapters,\\" answers to \\"Frequently Avoided Questions\\" and reading lists, making it easy to find important points. Many of Kawasaki's \\"exercises\\" are tongue-in-cheek, like, \\"Go to eBay and search for used Aeron chairs.\\" He got his start working at Apple Computer, marketing early MacIntoshes, and he now runs a venture capital firm, Garage Technology Ventures. He refers to both frequently, and most of the book's examples come from these venues, not from inside knowledge of other start-ups, even though the author has been involved in several. This isn't the only book you'll need to read when you decide to start a business, but we find that its iconoclastic pointers are useful and fun, and its sections on pitching, recruiting and branding, in particular, apply to businesses of any size.

McCandless grew up with ideal living conditions in a nice suburb of Washington D.C. His parents had money, his dad was an engineer. He got great grades and was a popular student along with being a great athlete. So what drove this young man into doing the things that he did? That is what you will find out in this book. Krakauer does extensive research on both McCandless's childhood and after he deserted his family. He ventures into the journey McCandless took and provides astonishing details that occurred along the way. McCandless abandoned both his family and life savings. He graduated from college with honors and gave away thousands of dollars to a charity. He then took his car and began traveling as a tramp. In the book you will learn about the people that he touched and encountered along the way. At one point he even ditched his car and began tramping by foot. There are numerous side plots in the story in which you will find out fascinating things the McCandless did. He had a number of odd jobs and traveled to many states and even out of the country. At one point along the way he decides that he is going to journey across through Alaska during the winter and live off the land. As all of you know Chris McCandless did not come out of that Alaskan wilderness alive but the way he got there was truly an amazing story. At the beginning of the book I thought that McCandless was and idiot for leaving what so many will never have and that he was just being ignorant. As the book went on I found myself gaining more and more respect for Chris and what he stood for. Now Krakauer does not answer the question of why McCandless did what he did, but that is a question that no one can answer. To hate and bad mouth McCandless for doing with his life what he wanted is absurd, because even if you don't agree with it, it was his life not yours.
B00005JO04|4.0|This films has several real strengths and thus is very suspenceful and thoughtful. I found two major strengths to the film, the method of allowing multiple story lines to develop and converge gradually while withholding information from the viewer so that the viewer is continually trying to figure out the plot. I will discuss those two strengths below and then I will end this review with a discussion of the weakest link in the chain, which is some of the conceptualization around the role of the United States in the international arena and the means by which US agencies will ensure that the US corporate interests are protected. <br /> <br />First, the film used the technique of truncating activities and  dialogue that would clue the viewer into the full scheme or plot of the film. For example, banker Christopher Plummer asks the youngest son of an Arabian state what he 'wants'. We never hear the answer. Only later do we learn that he wishes to be king which means disposal of his older brother. Thus the viewer must be on their toes during the entire film, trying to piece together the various plot lines of the film. <br /> <br />Second, the acting was superb with wonderful performances by Clooney who does a wonderful job of gradually becoming enraged by his employer - the CIA, Alexander Siggig as the idealistic and realistic eldest son of the Arabian king wishing to break from US influence over his father and his country, Jeffrey Wright as a lawyer investigating his own client's from the outside to determine if the Justice Department can uncover wrong doing in the major oil industries, Chris Cooper as an outspoken Texas Oil man, Christopher Plummer as the senior partner of a powerful Washington law firm that actually tells the CIA whom to assasinate, and Matt Damon as a stock specialist who befriends the young Arabian Prince and begins to serve as his financial advisor.  <br /> <br />However a carefully written and directed script and a great cast of actors does not necessarily make this a great film (a score of 5). The film is based on the premise that world wide petroleum supplies are drying up at a time when the Chinese demand for oil is increasing exponentially (which is true). Thus, it is in the best interest for the United States to control oil producing countries at all costs so that oil continues to flow to the USA un-interrupted (maybe true). Major oil corporations thus are able to command considerable political power and are able to influence the governement agencies to support their business enterprise (probably true). Therefore, when an Arab Prince decides to sign a contract with the Chinese for sale of oil and to cancel contracts with US defense contractors for overpriced weapons systems, the CIA actually asasinates this Prince at the bidding of the US oil giants as communicated through their power broker Washington attorney (very improbable and very doubtful). Of course the film is fiction and should be rated and reviewed as fiction, but many viewers may feel the film went one step too far when it indicates the CIA practices asasination at the request of the oil industry.  <br /> <br />Many entertaining aspects of the film rung very true - such as Hezbollah requiring approval of a CIA agent before they are allowed to operate in Lebannon as well as CIA bureaucrats practicing spin control when an agent is captured trying to asassinate an oil Prince. The most fascinating story line in the entire film was not the asasination story line which many reviewers found to be unrealistic, or the tragic Matt Damon storyline where his young son gets electrocuted at a swimming party, but rather the wonderful Jeffrey Wright storyline where an African American lawyer is asked to investigate the powerful clients of his law firm to find out the 'dirty laundry' before the US Justice Department finds any smoking guns. Wright not only finds the dirty laundry, but he negotiates giving up the unlucky small fry crooks with the Justice Department so that the major big boy corporate heads can continue to control world oil supplies with the assistance of US agencies for a gas guzzling nation of SUV drivers. <br /> <br />The far right will hate this film. The far left will love it. Whatever, it is thoughtful entertainment that does challenge the viewer to take a stand as to what they believe the role of the US should be in regard to protecting America's interest in oil consumption.

006054094X|5.0|This book, as one may well gueess from its status as a bestseller, is a riproaring triumph. It is a detective story, travelogue, and history book rolled into one, and is as beautifully crafted as one would expect from a man who has spent many years of his life putting it together. <br /> <br />Let's cut to the chase; the claim that Menzies makes - that the Chinese treasure fleets of 1421 discovered the Americas, Antarctica, Australia, and New Zealand long before any Europeans - is one which ruffles many feathers. Menzies argues that Colombus, Da Gama, Magellan, and Cook all followed in the wake of these Chinese discoveries, and in almost all cases, relied upon Chinese navigational and cartographic knowledge. This argument is no doubt controversial, and if this book is as widely read and accepted as it ought to be, there will soon be piles of history books all over the world which need to be replaced. <br /> <br />Menzies has mounds of evidence to support his claims, and that evidence is explained and discussed in this book with great clarity and intelligence. He argues that the clues left by the Chinese fleets take the form of porcelain, plants, animals, buildings, wrecked ships, and most conclusively, people. The author ties this evidence together and reconstructs the threads of the Chinese voyages with great mastery. Perhaps most impressive is the sheer volume of reading and research which Menzies has done in order to get to the point of publishing this book. <br /> <br />1421 is an important book, and one which is made accessible to all through Menzies' easy narrative style. It is difficult, in the face of the evidence which Menzies presents, to see the history of exploration in the same light after reading this book. At the most, 1421 has begun the process of rewriting history, and at the least, it poses important questions which ought to be explored elsewhere in more depth. Read this book, and decide for yourselves. Even if you do not agree with the conclusionsposited in 1421, you will go away knowing that you have still read a first class work.

0140177396|5.0|First published in 1937, this masterpiece of the Twentieth Century still resonates strongly today. The book is ostensibly the story of two men's friendship, but the themes which Steinbeck explores extend much further than is normal for a book of only one hundred or so pages. Hope, fear, love, justice, and friendship are all touched upon by Steinbeck's flowing prose. In addition, Steinbeck touches upon subjects which still impact on modern society to this day; racism and sexism. The book is also interesting for its representation of agricultural life in 1930s California. <br /> <br />The story offers the reader a fly on the wall's perspective as the two main protagonists, George and Lennie, take up their new jobs on a ranch in California's Salinas Valley. George is small and quick-witted, while Lennie is large and simple-minded. George tries his best to look after Lennie and to keep him out of harm's way and Lennie rewards him with loyalty. In the end though, George is unsuccessful in his attempts at helping Lennie avoid trouble and Steinbeck leaves it up to the reader to consider the consequences of this failure. <br /> <br />In 'Of Mice and Men' Steinbeck experiments with a genre of his own creation; the play / novelette. With this knowledge in mind, the book takes on a different aspect and the descriptions and dialogues appear to have been written with the stage in mind. This is just one example of how Steinbeck's mastery of literature becomes apparent upon reading this book. <br /> <br />This book deserves to be read; for Steinbeck's hard-hitting prose and his use of realistic dialogue, and also for his classic exploration of what friendship means.

After finding his uncles car with bullet holes in it, Alex discovers that he didn't work for a bank after all, he was a special agent for the MI6.  After only two weeks of training, they send him, posing as a computer geek who has won the competition to try out the first Stormbreaker revolutionary super computer, to pick up where his uncle left off.  His task... to find out what is going on at Sayle Enterprises, and stop the new Stormbreakers from being spread across the country.  Equipped with only some seemingly harmless supplies (such as zit cream that eats metal, a game boy that can scan, fax, emit smoke, or see through walls), Alex is shipped of to port talon.  Along his journey he meets many people such as an ex-circus knife catcher with scares from an accident and a professional hit man named Yassen Gregorovich.  Alex finds clues left by his uncle to help him find out what he already knew.  Once the people at Sayle Enterprises found out what he was really up to, they tried to get rid of him.  Alex is chased across a field by two security guards on ATVs and thrown into a large tank with a Portuguese man-of-war.  The action in this book is brought out even better by the author's great detail.  You will love this action filled, spy novel that answers all the questions of, \\"what would James Bond have been like as a teen?\\"

020161622X|5.0|This book has a lot of good advice.  Here's some of my favorites:<br /><br />- DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself).  So much unmaintainable code is written when you copy-n-paste stuff around.  The pragmatic programmer goes out of his way to minimize the amount of code, testing, and documentation that is duplicated.  I think if you take one thing away from this book...take this advice.<br /><br />- Design techniques, such as DBC (design-by-contract) that make sure that you define the pre-conditions, post-conditions, and invariants for each method or function you define.  This stuff is inherent in Eiffel, but he also talks about a Java library called iContract which accomplishes the same thing in Java.  Thinking about coding this way makes it easier to define tests and conveys to the caller the state the system should be in when the code is executed.<br /><br />- Know a scripting language.  A lot of programmers see PERL, Python or Ruby as something that sys admin's use.  However, these can be very powerful tools in your toolchest if you ever need to manipulate text, files, system resources, etc.<br /><br />- Minimize coupling.  I know we all know this...but it doesn't hurt to repeat it.

B000BYA5GO|4.0|\\"Lord of War\\" --in my humble opinion-- is an Americanized and fictionalized biography of the notorious Russian arms dealer Victor Bout (the real \\"death merchant\\") who literally \\"made a killing\\" since the fall of the Soviet Union selling weapons to pretty much anyone who could pay for them.<br /><br />\\"Lord of War\\" --when it sticks to the gunrunning-- is an excellent movie.  It does a particularly fine job demonstrating what people like Victor Bout made possible in places like Liberia and Sierra Leone (think \\"Lord of the Flies\\" in Africa).  Some of the vignettes are priceless like when Yuri (the character played by Nicolas Cage) evades having a freighter of his laden with contraband seized the authorities through a hastily improvised deception.  Another great moment is when we get to see happens to valuable property like cargo planes when they are left unattended in places like Liberia and Sierra Leone (think \\"chop shop\\" on an epic scale).<br /><br />The movie does have some problems with it that prevent me from giving it five stars:<br /><br />-The plotline involving Yuri's wife is pretty unbelievable.  If you are married to someone like Victor Bout for a long period of time and you profess to be oblivious to his business, you're either lying, being willfully blind, or are too stupid to live.<br /><br />-The idea that after Yuri had been indicted and arrested (and a trailer full of incriminating evidence seized as well), he could be sprung from jail by some shadowy US Army officer is ludicrous.  How do I know this?  Because, I did a study on another one of nature's noblemen Manuel Noriega some years back.  Even though he was once very useful to the US and in the pay of the CIA, once he was indicted for drug trafficking, it became impossible for the US to use him as proxie.  The same thing would apply in Yuri's case.  Once he was indicted, I'm sure that anyone who was making use of him would have dropped him like a hot potatoe.<br /><br />My final beef with the movie is the text that comes on the screen right before the credits role.  The words tell us --quite accurately-- that the world's biggest sellers of arms are the US and the other permanent members of the Security Council.<br /><br />That is very true, but what the movie doesn't tell the viewer is that the nature of US and British arms sales tends to be things like ships, planes, guided missiles, and other high-tech toys.  These items aren't the tools of atrocities like those committed in Sierra Leone and Liberia in the late 1990s.  Those things --AK-47s, machine-guns, are the items in Victor Bout's product line.  Lumping sales of weapons to countries at peace with themselves and their neighbors in with criminal sales of \\"gear\\" to people like Charles Tailor of Liberia and the hand-chopping \\"RUF\\" of Sierra Leone is completely unfair and is a gross distortion of the facts.ght before the credits role.
